title: Untitled
text: Your Stripe account username is the email address you used to register. If you’re not sure which email address you used, search your inboxes for previous Stripe emails to confirm.

title: Untitled
text: Any updates made to payout timing or method during this time will take effect after the waiting period. Check your estimated payout schedule at the Dashboard .

title: Untitled
text: Your first payout might take longer, depending on your industry risk level and country of operation. The waiting period can be up to 14 days for businesses in certain industries and up to 30 days in countries such as Brazil. See a full list of payout schedules by country .

title: Untitled
text: If you still haven’t received your payout after the designated waiting period see: Where is my payout? FAQ for missing and late payouts .

title: Untitled
text: Ensure the account number, routing number, and name match your bank statement. You must match the currency of the bank account to the currency in your Payout settings . Use the same name (either individual name or company name) from your bank statement.

title: Untitled
text: If a payout hasn’t arrived according to its expected delivery date, there can be several reasons as to why. Check both your dashboard or email to see if additional information has been requested from you in order to complete the payout.

title: Untitled
text: Lost your phone, changed your phone number, or having problems with SMS? Follow this troubleshooting guide or update your phone number .

title: Untitled
text: Don’t have your backup code and still can’t complete two-step authentication? Follow these steps to remove two-step authentication from your account.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe is a payments processor that works with businesses to help them accept payments through their websites, apps, and in store. If you see a charge from “STRIPE” on your credit card statement, it’s likely you purchased something from a business that uses our services and the business name is just not reflected in the bank statement descriptor. Use the secure charge lookup tool to identify the business.

title: Untitled
text: If you don't recognize the business name or want a refund, reach out to the business directly. Stripe is unable to issue refunds on their behalf.

title: Untitled
text: If you are unable to get in touch with the business, they are unresponsive, or you believe the business might be fraudulent, reach out to your banks. They may have recommendations for how to proceed, such as opening a dispute .

title: Untitled
text: Each card network has its own formal, structured process for handling disputes between cardholders and merchants, but at a high level they are all essentially the same. The process is described here:

title: Untitled
text: When a dispute occurs, the disputed amount plus the dispute fee is pulled from your Stripe balance by the card network until a decision is reached by the card network on who should win the dispute. Stripe plays no part in the dispute decision itself, but we do provide tools to help you challenge the dispute to give you the best chance of winning. Not challenging the dispute can be seen as an acceptance of the dispute by the networks, so submitting evidence is your best chance of winning the dispute.

title: Untitled
text: When you receive a dispute, you will have one decision to make in the beginning - will you challenge the dispute or not. You should review the dispute and the dispute claim from your Dashboard to understand if you think the dispute was valid or not from the perspective of your customer. On top of this, you should assess whether or not you have evidence to counter the dispute. With these factors in mind, you can make your decision on whether or not to counter the dispute. If you choose not to challenge it, you can either ignore the dispute and do nothing, or explicitly accept the dispute:

title: Untitled
text: In your dashboard, you’ll be given a timeline on when evidence should be submitted, so if you do choose to counter the dispute, you’ll have time to gather your evidence. After you’ve made the decision to counter the dispute, you’ll need to begin gathering your evidence for submission.  Disputes are a normal and common part of the payments ecosystem, but if you don't have a lot of experience with them, they might seem complex. We provide you with everything you need to know about what to include in your evidence submission so that you can navigate the process:

title: Untitled
text: Depending on the reason the customer disputed the payment, there are a number of different types of evidence that you can supply to counter the claim. For example, a payment disputed for the reason “ Product not received” can be countered with evidence of delivery by the customer signing for the goods.

title: Untitled
text: The evidence you provide the issuer at this step of the process is the only communication between you and the issuer. There are no other opportunities to communicate during this process. Based on the evidence you give, the issuer will make a single, final decision about whether the dispute is won or lost.

title: Untitled
text: The best way to deal with disputes is to prevent them from occurring in the first place. This might not always be possible but learning from past disputes can help prevent future disputes. Check out our docs on how you can best prevent disputes for your account:

title: Untitled
text: For platforms working on 1099 tax forms for connected accounts, see Stripe Documentation . For Express or Custom connected accounts, see Express Support Site .

title: Untitled
text: The 1099-K form is a purely informational document that summarizes the sales activity of your account. It is designed to assist you in reporting your taxes. For more information on what is included on your 1099-K form, see Information included on a 1099-K form .

title: Untitled
text: Every year, the United States’ IRS and certain states requires that Stripe provide a 1099-K for each Stripe account that meets all of the following criteria in the previous calendar year:

title: Untitled
text: Stripe issues 1099-K forms to all eligible U.S.-based users who accept payments, regardless of their business type or activity. The 1099-K is provided to both the account holder and the IRS, as well as some U.S. states.

title: Untitled
text: State filing requirements might differ from federal requirements. View the full list of state filing thresholds in this table .

title: Untitled
text: Prior to calendar year 2024, the 1099-K threshold applied to accounts based in the U.S. and having $20,000 USD in total gross volume and 200 transactions.

title: Untitled
text: If your business qualifies for a 1099-K, your 1099-K for the previous calendar year will be available to download from the Documents section of the Dashboard by January 31st . We notify account admins via email when the form is available.

title: Untitled
text: If you didn't qualify for a 1099-K and would like to see your payment transaction history for the previous year, see How can I review all my payment transactions for the tax year? .

title: Untitled
text: You can export your 1099-K forms from the Documents section of the Dashboard . You can download any available 1099-K PDF that we have prepared for you.

title: Untitled
text: If you no longer have access to your Stripe account, Stripe will mail the 1099-K using the latest address information that you’ve provided.

title: Untitled
text: If your 1099-K includes incorrect tax details, you can update these details from the Documents section of the Dashboard .

title: Untitled
text: If you need to split the volume of your generated 1099-K form between two separate legal entities, contact Stripe Support .

title: Untitled
text: If you believe the amount in box 1a is incorrect, see the section below on understanding the total reported volume.

title: Untitled
text: These additional fees, refunds, and adjustments are not deducted from your total charges when calculating your gross volume and reporting to the IRS. Stripe must report total gross volume and cannot update amounts on 1099 tax forms.

title: Untitled
text: Starting with tax year 2023, accounts with Administrator access can use the Stripe Dashboard to export the transaction log of each 1099 form. A transaction log lists the Stripe transactions that have contributed to a form’s total. This log allows you to audit transaction discrepancies and answer questions which transactions Stripe includes in their tax forms. For a detailed step by step guide, check out: 1099-K forms issued by Stripe - Reconciliation Report

title: Untitled
text: For tax years 2022 and before, contact support to get the reconciliation report for your 1099-K form for a given tax year.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe provides a 1099-K form for each unique tax identification number (TIN), such as a Social Security Number (SSN) or Employer Identification Number (EIN), that meets the IRS or state processing threshold. If you received a 1099-K and didn't expect to, it might be because:

title: Untitled
text: If you received a 1099-K and still do not believe you should have, we recommend going over the steps outlined in the reconciliation section of this article.

title: Untitled
text: If your accountant needs to calculate your potential deductions for Stripe fees, refunds, and adjustments, this can be accessed through your Dashboard:

title: Untitled
text: 1099-Ks from Stripe to Connect Custom and Express platforms will also include all transactions processed through their connected accounts. Per IRC §6050W, Stripe is obligated to send a 1099-K to our payee in the fund flow chain. This means 1099-Ks from Stripe to Connect Custom and Express platforms report the full volume to the US platform on the 1099-K.

title: Untitled
text: A 1099-K is only informational. It is not a statement of revenue or income, and should not result in any additional tax being owed. The lower true earned income amount should be reflected on your personal or corporate income tax return. Income tax returns allow you to indicate adjustments, expenses, and other deductions, like amounts passed on to connected accounts that should reduce the initial gross receipts/income amount.

title: Untitled
text: If you are a Connect platform looking for information on how 1099s should be issued to managed accounts, see: U.S. tax reporting for Connect platforms .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe's obligations are to issue 1099-K forms to all eligible US-based users who accept payments, independent of their business type or activity. Even for tax-exempt activities, which may potentially include the acceptance of donations, Stripe is obligated to issue a 1099-K form. The 1099-K is for informational purposes only. We recommend consulting a tax advisor to learn more about this form and how you should use it.

title: Untitled
text: We recommend talking with your tax advisors when preparing your tax forms, but here are some links that you might find useful as a sole proprietor:

title: Untitled
text: You can view a list of available local payment methods that you can accept in your Payment methods settings .

title: Untitled
text: Click Turn on next to the payment method you want to accept. Depending on the payment method, you may be prompted to provide additional information required by the scheme.

title: Untitled
text: Depending on your Stripe integration, you may need to take additional steps to start accepting that payment method on your site. We recommend using a hosted integration like Checkout so the payment method is available right away, without any code changes.

title: Untitled
text: If you use the Hosted Invoice Page , you’ll need to set the payment methods that you want to accept for invoices on the Invoice Template settings page.

title: Untitled
text: You will also be able to edit which payment methods you want to accept for a specific invoice in the Invoices and Subscriptions editors.

title: Untitled
text: Account-related email notifications must go to the owner listed for the Stripe account. If you need to change the account owner, see Change Account Owner .

title: Untitled
text: If you want account-related notifications to go to someone who is not the account owner, you can set up e-mail forwarding to automatically forward on certain emails from Stripe to other email addresses. Instructions on how to do this using Gmail can be found here .

title: Untitled
text: If you would like someone else to receive payment-related notifications, such as payment successes, failures, and disputes, you can add them as a team member and adjust their email notifications accordingly.

title: Untitled
text: Reset your password if needed. You’ll receive a confirmation email once your password is reset. If you have two-step authentication enabled, you’ll need to complete two-step authentication.

title: Untitled
text: Passkeys offer a secure, passwordless login to the Stripe Dashboard using biometrics (such as Touch ID, Windows Hello, or Face ID), a device PIN, or a hardware security key. Passkeys can also be used as a two-step authentication method if you log in with a username and password.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe might email you a verification link to confirm your identity and protect your account when you attempt to log in or make sensitive changes. To complete verification, keep the original tab open and click the email’s Verify identity link using the same device and browser as the original tab.

title: Untitled
text: Want even more security? Verify using a hardware security key , Windows Hello or Touch ID device , or passkey .

title: Untitled
text: Clicking the Verify identity link sometimes results in a "We couldn't verify your identity" error. These are some common causes:

title: Untitled
text: If you’ve lost your phone or changed your phone number, you can update the number where SMS two-step authentication verification codes are sent.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe emails you when your account is accessed from a new device and location. If you received an unrecognized login email and you don’t recognize the login:

title: Untitled
text: To enable two-step authentication, open the Personal details page on the Stripe Dashboard. Find the Two-step authentication section, click Add authentication method and follow the prompts. We recommend enabling at least two methods to prevent account lockouts.

title: Untitled
text: If you're a Stripe team administrator, you can require all team members to use two-step authentication on the Team settings page .

title: Untitled
text: If your authenticator app syncs or exports secret keys, no action is needed to switch devices. Otherwise, follow the steps below depending on if you can sign in or not.

title: Untitled
text: To use the authenticator app on your new device, update your two-step authentication settings in the Dashboard. This process invalidates any verification codes on the old device.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe requires some users to enable two-step authentication when using the Dashboard for enhanced security. Logging in with two-step authentication provides an additional security measure to protect your Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: If you are sharing an account between multiple people, use the Teams feature so each user can use their own credentials and device for two-step authentication.

title: Untitled
text: Backup codes let you disable two-step authentication on your account and log in if you can’t complete the authentication step. Keeping it secure is very important, your password and backup code can give someone full access to your account.

title: Untitled
text: If you lost your backup code and can still log in to your account, generate a new code from your two-step authentication settings . Doing this will invalidate the old code.

title: Untitled
text: Follow these instructions to remove two-step authentication from your account if you can’t complete the authentication step and don’t have your backup code.

title: Untitled
text: If you suspect your backup code is compromised, go to your two-step authentication settings and generate a new one as soon as possible. Doing this will invalidate the old code.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe will show you a backup code when you finish setting up two-step authentication. It’ll only be displayed once, so it’s important to write it down and keep it safe.

title: Untitled
text: If you use a USB flash drive, we strongly recommend using a dedicated USB drive for backup codes and only plug it in when necessary. This makes it more difficult for malware to access the credentials.

title: Untitled
text: The current owner of a Stripe account can transfer ownership to someone else, depending on the user's existing account access and permissions. They might need to transfer ownership if someone is leaving their organization, or if the responsibility of Stripe account ownership is shifting.

title: Untitled
text: For Stripe accounts in Brazil, the transfer of ownership is not allowed in case of individual or sole proprietorship accounts (linked to a CPF). Learn more about updating tax information in Brazil .

title: Untitled
text: Only the current owner of a Stripe account can transfer ownership. If that person is no longer with the company, reach out to Stripe Support.

title: Additional Information
text: To close a Stripe account, the owner must navigate to Settings > Business > Account details in the Dashboard, ensure they are logged into the correct account, and click Close account . Before closing, it is important to pay out any existing balances. Closing a Stripe account does not release the owner from any liability related to the account balance. Each Stripe account must be closed individually.

title: Additional Information
text: The owner of a Stripe account can close the account by navigating to Settings > Business > Account details in the Dashboard. On the Account details page, scroll to the bottom and click Close account .

title: Additional Information
text: You may see the below error in your Stripe dashboard, and this error is caused by a mismatch of the tax information in your dashboard and the tax information on file with the IRS.

title: Additional Information
text: “ The IRS couldn’t recognize your tax ID and name together. Make sure this information exactly matches your official IRS-issued documentation (e.g., Letter 147C or SS-4 Confirmation letter). You can also upload these documents. ”

title: Additional Information
text: It is required that the information you enter for your legal name and tax ID number exactly matches the information displayed on your official IRS-issued documentation, such as your SS-4 confirmation letter or your Letter 147C.

title: Additional Information
text: For example, if the entity name on your Letter 147C says: “Jane Doe-Smith” you would need to type this in exactly as it appears including the hyphen.

title: Additional Information
text: See Using IRS documentation as reference when entering business name and Tax ID Number (TIN) for US-based businesses for formatting examples when referencing the Letter 147C and SS-4 Confirmation letters.

title: Additional Information
text: If your TIN was issued more than 3 months ago, the legal name and tax ID in the dashboard match the information on your SS-4 confirmation letter, and Stripe is unable to verify it with IRS records, you will need to call the IRS at 1-800-829-4933 and request a Letter 147C (the record of how your entity is filed with the IRS).

title: Additional Information
text: If Stripe is still unable to verify the information on your recently obtained Letter 147C, upload a copy of your Letter 147C to the Dashboard .

title: What can you expect during this process?
text: Stripe maintains an important responsibility within the financial ecosystem to protect our users and the businesses or consumers they serve. To do so, we must have a thorough understanding of each user’s business model, financial situation, and the potential credit risk of the business. We do this through a process called credit underwriting.

title: What can you expect during this process?
text: During the underwriting process, you can expect a review of your business model, billing practices, product usage, processing history, and financial stability, among other things. We’ll request for your updated financial information, as well have questions about your recent processing history with other payment processors, if applicable.

title: What can you expect during this process?
text: Generally, businesses that take payments far in advance of delivery of goods and services pose a higher credit risk for payment processors like Stripe. Additionally, the sheer volume of refunds or disputes based on the size of a user may also be associated with higher risk.

title: What can you expect during this process?
text: Given elevated levels of risk, users must demonstrate operational and financial strength to continue fulfilling their business obligations (e.g. delivery of goods or services purchased, refunds, disputes and associated fees).

title: What can you expect during this process?
text: Based on certain internal criteria, your business may fall into a category that requires manual underwriting. When this is the case, your application will be assessed by one of our underwriters. Providing complete information in a timely manner helps ensure there are no unforeseen delays or unexpected risk mitigations that could impact your business.

title: What can you expect during this process?
text: If you are unable to provide the requested documentation or information, let us know as soon as possible. We would be happy to discuss with you what, if any, alternative information could be provided.

title: What can you expect during this process?
text: Data security and confidentiality are incredibly important to us. The information you share is intended solely for the purpose of underwriting and will be shared only on a need-to-know basis within the Stripe risk team.

title: What can you expect during this process?
text: Stripe also conducts periodic account reviews of your business to ensure that it is in good health as it evolves over time. Reviews are a common practice in the financial services industry. The information collected during this process is used to confirm that Stripe has an accurate, up-to-date assessment of your business and helps Stripe protect all the users on our platform, as well as their customers.

title: Untitled
text: Open the Personal details page on the Stripe Dashboard and confirm your email address is correct. If it’s not, click Edit in the User section and update it.

title: Untitled
text: If you find the email in your junk or spam folder, mark it as “not spam” and save Stripe’s email address to your contacts.

title: Untitled
text: If a customer didn’t receive a receipt email, find the payment in the Dashboard and click Send Receipt under Receipt history .

title: Untitled
text: Your Stripe account username is the email address you used to register. If you’re not sure which email address you used, search your inboxes for previous Stripe emails to confirm.

title: Untitled
text: If the team member doesn't have a Stripe login yet, they will be invited to create one and then can access the account. If they have an existing account, they will be prompted to log into Stripe and can then switch between accounts .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe may require users to upload a photo of a government-issued photo ID and a selfie for identity verification to the Dashboard . The photos must be clear and well-lit without any obstructions. Use a mobile device's camera for better quality.

title: Untitled
text: In some cases, Stripe will require you to upload an image of your photo ID and selfie to confirm your identity. You'll need to take a photo of an accepted form of ID, such as a driver's license or passport. Sometimes we’ll also need to capture an image of your face in addition. Due to the highly sensitive nature of your verification documents, Stripe can only accept documents which are uploaded through the Dashboard. Do not send documents by email.

title: Untitled
text: If you don’t receive a text message, you can use a QR code instead to access the link. In the Dashboard there is an option to display a QR code on the screen. Then use your phone’s camera (if QR code detection is supported) or other barcode scanning app to scan the code and access the link.

title: Untitled
text: Check that you’ve given Stripe permission to access your webcam—if you block permissions to your camera, refer to Chrome, Safari, or Edge documentation on allowing access to use your webcam.

title: Untitled
text: If you don't have a webcam, in the Dashboard there is an option to switch to another device. You'll be prompted to enter your mobile phone number and Stripe will send a link to your phone to start the process.

title: Untitled
text: From the Support center you can view active and closed support cases, upload files requested by Stripe, and respond to ongoing cases. The Support center is found under the Help menu (question mark icon) in the top right hand corner of the Dashboard.

title: Creating products and prices using the Dashboard
text: You can add additional Prices for that same product from the same page. This could be useful if you want to offer the same Product in a different currency or with a different interval (for example, yearly vs. monthly.

title: Creating products and prices using the Dashboard
text: You can also choose to archive or delete your product if it is no longer active. We recommend archiving and not deleting, as to make sure you preserve historical information. Once deleted, you will not be able to recover any information about the product.

title: Creating products and prices using the Dashboard
text: You can use the Copy to live mode button at the top right to copy your product from test mode to live mode when you're ready.

title: Creating products and prices using the Dashboard
text: If the price has already been used, you can only edit the description and the trial period of a Price. For prices that have not been used, you can edit pricing structure as needed:

title: Creating products and prices using the Dashboard
text: Once you set up products and prices you can see how you can set up subscriptions or invoices here .

title: Creating products and prices using the Dashboard
text: To learn more, see Prices Guide . If you are interested in updating your integration to use Price objects directly, see this migration guide .

title: Why was my payout date changed or postponed?
text: If your payout date keeps getting pushed out to a future date, this is most likely due to an account verification requirement that still needs to be completed. In order to resume processing payouts, the owner of the Stripe account should check both the Dashboard and email to see if additional information was requested.

title: Why was my payout date changed or postponed?
text: If you updated your bank account details after a payout was initiated, then it will go to the previous bank account .

title: Why was my payout date changed or postponed?
text: Confirm the payout was sent to the bank account you expect. On the Dashboard , navigate to the payout and check the payout destination under Account details . Often users find a typo in the bank details, or the payout was sent to a different bank account than they thought.

title: Why was my payout date changed or postponed?
text: If your expected payout was sent less than 5 business days ago, your payout funds have left Stripe and the payout is being processed by your bank. Bank processing can be delayed by weekends and holidays. Once the bank has finished processing your payout, the funds will be deposited into your account automatically.

title: Why was my payout date changed or postponed?
text: If this is your first payout, Stripe typically schedules your initial payout for 7-14 days after you successfully receive your first payment. Your first payout might take longer, depending on your industry risk level and country of operation. Subsequent payouts follow your account’s payout schedule .

title: Why was my payout date changed or postponed?
text: All other payouts can take up to 5 business days after the expected post date. If you haven’t received your payout after 5 business days have passed, contact your bank with the payout information, including the trace ID , to help them locate the funds. If your bank still can’t find the payout, ask them for a written statement confirming that the funds haven’t been received.

title: Why was my payout date changed or postponed?
text: If you are an Express Connected account using global or cross-border payouts , or a Custom Connected Account,  ask your Platform to contact Stripe Support with this written statement from your bank. Due to terms of service agreements, Stripe Support is only able to provide details regarding the payout to your Platform.

title: Why was my payout date changed or postponed?
text: If you are a Platform, Standard Connected account, Express Connected account using non-global payouts, or Direct Stripe user, contact Stripe Support with this written statement from your bank confirming that they have not received the funds from Stripe.

title: Why was my payout date changed or postponed?
text: Make sure to check your Dashboard or email for notifications or information from us on if Stripe needs more information or documents from you.

title: Untitled
text: Payouts are processed automatically on a daily basis. Manual, weekly, and monthly payout schedules aren’t available for accounts in India.

title: Untitled
text: Payouts aren’t posted during the weekend or public holidays. If the expected post date falls on a weekend or holiday, it’s paid out on the following business day.

title: Untitled
text: Daily payout funds paid out to your bank account include payments processed five business days prior for international cards and two business days prior for Indian cards.

title: Untitled
text: There is a seven day waiting period for the first payout. Several factors can extend the waiting period, including operating in a high-risk industry. Stripe processes subsequent payouts daily according to the funds availability timelines listed above.
