text: In order for you to receive funds, Stripe (or your platform) makes payouts to your bank account. See more details for payout schedules and payment availability in Brazil:

title: Untitled
text: Payouts are not posted during the weekend—if the expected post date falls over a weekend, it will be paid out on the following business day.

title: Untitled
text: That means that the daily payouts to your bank account include payments processed 30, 5 or 2 calendar days prior (depending on payment method).

title: Untitled
text: The first payout may take longer for a number of reasons , including being in a high-risk industry. See Waiting on your first Stripe payout? What you need to know.

title: Untitled
text: After our review, if your account is approved, the Crypto payment method will become active in the Dashboard . If the payment method appears as pending, we’re still reviewing your candidacy and might reach out to you for more details.

title: Untitled
text: We're working quickly to add the ability to expand this capability to more accounts. If you're unable to onboard or don't see Crypto as a payment method in your Settings, please reach out to pay-with-crypto@stripe.com .

title: Untitled
text: When using Pay with Crypto, your customers can pay in USDC on Ethereum, Solana, and Polygon or in USDP on Ethereum and Solana, while funds will settle in your Stripe balance in USD.

title: Untitled
text: If your customer successfully paid using Pay with Crypto, you will see the payment reflected as “successful” on the Dashboard .

title: Untitled
text: After the refund is completed, the payment will update to refunded on your Stripe Dashboard . Your customer will receive the refund as stablecoins in their original wallet.

title: Untitled
text: Instant Bank Payments let your customers pay with a US bank account with Link . Unlike ACH Direct Debit , Instant Bank Payments deliver instant confirmation and faster settlement, protection from common ACH failures, and an accelerated checkout experience for your customers. They are best for businesses that need to deliver their products and services immediately and don't want to manage the risk of processing ACH transactions.

title: Untitled
text: Instant Bank Payments are automatically enabled when you turn Link on, subject to eligibility requirements. On sites where it’s enabled, Link saves and autofills payment details for customers.

title: Untitled
text: Unlike ACH Direct Debit, where it can take up to four business days to successfully process a transaction, Instant Bank Payments are instantly confirmed. Settlement timing matches your card payments and you're protected from bank-initiated returns that might occur after authorization. Learn more about these US bank debit options .

title: Untitled
text: If you have enabled ACH Direct Debit on Payment Element or Checkout, they'll see it as a US bank account option.

title: Untitled
text: Instant Bank Payments are available with every Link integration, if eligible. Just ensure Link is turned on in your payment method settings and it will be automatically presented as a payment option to your US customers. See the technical documentation for details on how to view Instant Bank Payment transactions.

title: Untitled
text: Not all businesses and transactions are eligible for this payment method. Instant Bank Payments will be presented as a payment option during a session only when certain risk criteria are met. Some examples are:

title: Untitled
text: Disputes with Instant Bank Payments behave like cards, not like ACH Direct Debit. Like cards, when a dispute is created, Stripe debits your balance for the payment amount and dispute fee. Disputes can be viewed and challenged from within the Stripe Dashboard .

title: Untitled
text: With bank debits, customers can generally dispute a payment through their bank for up to 60 calendar days after a debit on a personal account, or up to 2 business days for a business account. In rare instances, a customer might be able to successfully dispute a debit payment outside these standard dispute timelines.

title: Untitled
text: To boost your conversion and revenue, you can opt into Stripe cash back offers for your customers who choose to pay with Link using their bank account. There is no cost to you or your business. Manage your participation in this program at any time via the Settings page . To redeem the offer, customers must check out with their bank account and then the discount will be automatically deposited within 3-5 days. See eligibility details .

title: Untitled
text: When using two-day settlement for ACH, payments will be made on Same Day ACH rails. If a payment fails after funds have been made available in your Stripe balance, Stripe will immediately remove those funds from your Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: Be aware of these additional risks. You might have transactions that pay out from your Stripe balance that later fail for common errors such as insufficient funds (NSF).

title: Untitled
text: US businesses in good standing will typically be eligible for two-day settlement after processing on Stripe for a minimum of 120 days.

title: Untitled
text: If you have opted into two-day settlement and your account fails to meet eligibility requirements on an ongoing basis, your eligibility may be revoked and your processing will revert back to standard timing.

title: Untitled
text: Same Day ACH is an improvement to the ACH network that allows for faster processing of ACH transactions. This does not mean that funds are available and confirmed on the same day. The customer’s bank still has 2 business days to send a return, so payments will take 3-4 business days to be processed and confirmed (compared to 4-5 business days for standard ACH). For ACH Direct Debit transactions with two-day settlement timing, payments under 1,000,000 USD submitted before 2:00pm US/Eastern Time will be processed on Same Day ACH rails. Payments above this limit or submitted after this cutoff time will be processed the next day.

title: Webhooks
text: This guide describes how Connect platforms can allow their Japan-based connected accounts to accept JCB payments. Connected accounts in other countries can accept JCB cards through the card_payments capability. In Japan, connected accounts accept JCB cards through the jcb_payments capability, which is automatically requested when you request card_payments .

title: Webhooks
text: While your connected accounts can start accepting these cards immediately, JCB automatically reviews all accounts. In some cases, JCB may reject your connected account, or request additional information about it or its owner. In this case, Stripe sends a capability.updated webhook and reaches out to you by email. Until the connected account is approved by JCB, Stripe temporarily pauses the ability of the connected account to accept new JCB payments. Any JCB payments that were processed before the pause are automatically refunded.

title: Webhooks
text: When JCB has made a decision on the application of your account, Stripe notifies you using a capability.updated webhook. You may want to use this information to hide JCB acceptance logos if you create your own custom checkout screen.

title: Webhooks
text: Details on the account’s change of status is also sent over email to the platform account and you can request a new review for your connected account.

title: Webhooks
text: You can verify the status of your connected account’s JCB acceptance by querying the status of the jcb_payments capability via the Capabilities API .

title: Webhooks
text: After providing answers about your Stripe integration on your regional Connect settings , you are able to start using the capability for your connected accounts.

title: Webhooks
text: If you received an email (subject: Simplified JCB acceptance for your connected accounts) in February 2025, your platform is included in an upgrade from the legacy JCB behavior:

title: Webhooks
text: For Express connected accounts, Stripe’s hosted onboarding will show the appropriate errors when validation fails. If you use Custom connected accounts, you will need to return the validation errors in your application.

title: Webhooks
text: If you create payments without using on_behalf_of (so your platform processes card payments for your connected accounts), or you do not plan to create new Japan-based connected accounts, these changes likely do not have any impact for you.

title: Webhooks
text: For older platforms, you need to request the jcb_payments capability manually when creating the account. If your platform account was created before Oct 17, 2024, or if you didn’t receive our email notification (subject: Simplified JCB acceptance for your connected accounts) in February 2025, your platform uses the legacy JCB process. If you encounter an error when requesting the capability, please reach out to japan-jcb-payments@stripe.com .

title: Webhooks
text: Your connected accounts can start to accept JCB cards after JCB approves them. In some cases, JCB requests additional information or actions to be taken from you, or your connected account. If so, Stripe notifies you by email.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Terminal is EMV-enabled to help protect you against payments from fraudulent and counterfeit cards. When you use Stripe Terminal, the bank is generally liable for fraudulent-type disputes filed, but there are some network exceptions to this.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe offers a mobile application to access the Dashboard for both iOS and Android devices. Use the app to view business metrics, track and manage payments and customers, and initiate payouts. IOS users can also sign up for Stripe via the app. You can also accept in-person payments (such as Tap to Pay), generate invoices, and create payment links and subscriptions. Learn more about the app and its capabilities .

title: Untitled
text: The Dashboard mobile app is available in 14 languages, as set by your device language via system preferences. The app is available for accounts that access the Dashboard, but excludes accounts with access to the Express Dashboard or accounts that do not have access to a Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: The iOS and Android Stripe Dashboard apps enable you to accept payments in person or create online payments. Learn more about in-person payments in this article .

title: Untitled
text: The payout reconciliation report (CSV) can either be downloaded from the Dashboard or the Reporting API. Data will typically be available the day after a payout is created. Recommended for most users.

title: Untitled
text: For automatic payouts, the Dashboard page displays a summary and breakdown of the transactions that were included in the payout. Recommended for one-off queries.

title: Untitled
text: The balance_transactions Sigma table includes automatic_transfer_id , which describes the automatic payout that the balance transaction was included in. Recommended for custom reports.

title: Untitled
text: For API integrations, you can query the Balance Transactions endpoint passing the relevant payout ID in the payout parameter. For most payouts, data will be available within a few minutes of payout creation, which will be reflected in the reconciliation_status field on the Payout object. Alternatively, you can subscribe to the payout.reconciliation_completed webhook.

title: Untitled
text: Due to the nature of manual payouts , it is not possible to see these breakdowns, as there is no explicit connection between charges or specific activity and the amount decided upon to be paid.

title: Untitled
text: Your payout schedule refers to how often Stripe sends money to your bank account. Where supported, payouts default to daily, but can be configured to weekly, monthly, or manual on the Payouts tab of the Dashboard (admin access is required to configure the payouts).

title: Untitled
text: However, the payouts schedule doesn't control how long it takes your pending balance to become available. For example, if your account operates on a daily payout schedule with a 3 business day payout speed , Stripe pays out funds daily from transactions captured 3 business days earlier.

title: Untitled
text: See the Stripe documentation for more details and country specific considerations . Additionally, certain currencies have a minimum payout amount that your available account balance needs to exceed before a payout can be initiated.

title: Untitled
text: Most banks will post received funds on the same day they are received. Sometimes, banks may take 2-3 additional days to post funds. Also, payouts on weekends or bank holidays won’t be accepted by your bank until the next business day.

title: Untitled
text: Your payout schedule refers to how often Stripe sends money to your bank account. For example, you can set the payouts to "daily" or to wait until you specify  ("manual").

title: Untitled
text: The payouts schedule doesn't control how long it takes your pending balance to become available. For example, if your account operates on a daily payout schedule with a 3 business day payout speed , Stripe pays out funds daily from transactions captured 3 business days earlier.

title: Untitled
text: See the Stripe documentation for more details and country specific considerations . Additionally, certain currencies have a minimum payout amount that your available account balance needs to exceed before a payout can be initiated.

title: How do I update my bank account info?
text: Bank account details can be updated at any time. However, if a payout is already in transit, it will be paid out to the previous bank account and not to the new one.

title: How do I update my bank account info?
text: Stripe creates payouts in advance of their post date to ensure that funds reach your bank account on the date that they are expected. If there is a payout showing in your Dashboard as “n transit” or “paid” any changes to your bank account information will not retroactively apply to these payouts and will only apply to the next payout.

title: How do I update my bank account info?
text: Payouts are sent to the bank account on file at the time the payout is initiated. If that account is closed, banks will then either inform Stripe that the bank account is closed and return the funds to your account automatically or contact you directly to disperse the funds. It can take up to 5 business days for the money to be returned to Stripe.

title: How do I update my bank account info?
text: You should contact your old bank to understand what will happen to the funds. You will need to provide the following information: bank account details, date expected, exact amount, and payor (Stripe). You can find these details at the Dashboard .

title: How do I update my bank account info?
text: If you haven’t received a payment, it’s possible the bank details were entered incorrectly (either a typo or not the account you thought it would go to). Go to the Settings page of the Dashboard , select Business Settings , and correct your bank details if necessary .

title: How do I update my bank account info?
text: If the bank account information added to your Stripe account exists (the account number and/or routing number exist) at the time the payout went "in transit", your payouts was sent there.

title: How do I update my bank account info?
text: If your payout is missing or has failed, you may have received an email with the subject line “Action required to resume payouts from your Stripe balance”, stating that “Your bank notified us that they could not process this payout” with a call to action to update your bank account. This  indicates that your bank account may have been denylisted due to an underlying issue, such as:

title: How do I update my bank account info?
text: Confirm that the bank account details associated with your Stripe account are correct. Then, work with your bank to ensure that your account is active, the bank details are correct, and the bank has allowlisted Stripe’s ACH IDs . After you've confirmed these details with your bank, if you're still unable to pay out to this bank account, contact Stripe Support with one of the following required documentation:

title: Untitled
text: Depending on the country, Stripe offers a number of different payout schedule options . You can choose to automatically have funds paid out daily, weekly, or monthly. You can also set a custom payout schedule by setting your payout schedule to Manual and building a custom schedule in your Stripe integration backend.

title: Untitled
text: If you turn off automatic payouts in the Dashboard, you must manually send funds to your bank account. You can do this either in the Payouts section of the Dashboard or by creating payouts using the API.

title: Untitled
text: Automatic and manual payout settings does not mean your payouts will arrive the next day. Automatic payouts will arrive according to your payout schedule . Manual payouts typically arrive 1-4 business days after the payout is initiated.

title: Additional Information
text: When a payment is received, it appears as a pending balance in your Dashboard (minus any Stripe fees). This balance is available to pay out instantly for up to 24 hours or the creation time of your next scheduled payout, whichever comes first.

title: Additional Information
text: If an Instant Payout isn't manually initiated within that window, the funds are paid out according to your standard payout schedule . Once a standard deposit is initiated, those funds aren't available for Instant Payouts and the Instant Payouts balance is updated accordingly. Monitor the status of your payouts on the Payouts tab of the Dashboard .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe may debit a user's bank account if their balance goes negative to ensure timely refunds and reduce customer disputes.

title: Untitled
text: A Standard Stripe account is a conventional Stripe account controlled directly by the account holder. A user with a Standard account is able to log in to the Dashboard , can process charges on their own, and can disconnect their account from a platform. You are also a Standard account if you are a Connect platform.

title: Untitled
text: We may debit your bank account if your Stripe balance goes into the negative. We do this to ensure that any pending refunds on your Stripe account can be fulfilled in a timely manner, which will reduce the risk of customer disputes.

title: Untitled
text: Your available Stripe balance may go into the negative if the cost of refunds, disputes, or Stripe fees is greater than the existing balance. If your Stripe account has a negative balance, you won’t be able to issue refunds until the balance is returned to a positive state.

title: Untitled
text: As noted in the Stripe Services Agreement , you agree to allow Stripe to debit funds from your bank account to cover amounts you owe to Stripe. This includes negative balances on your Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: It’s important that we ensure your account does not hold a negative balance for long periods of time, as it may delay refunds to your customers, which could result in disputes and related fees.

title: Untitled
text: Continuous disputes may result in your business being added to a card network monitoring program . For this reason, we need to initiate the debit as a response to a negative balance.

title: Untitled
text: The debit attempt will fail, and you may incur an overdraft or dishonor fee depending on your bank’s policies. We will make multiple subsequent attempts to debit your bank account in the event that a debit fails, so we strongly advise you to ensure you have enough funds in your bank account to cover the debit amount.

title: Untitled
text: Yes. You can change your bank account by updating the bank account linked to your Stripe account via the Dashboard. This will also change the bank account to which your payouts are sent.

title: Untitled
text: Note that updating your bank account does not affect Stripe's ability to debit the prior bank account under the SSA.

title: Untitled
text: Standard Stripe accounts will only be debited if their negative balance is greater than 10 units of their local currency (e.g., 10 USD, 10 GBP, 10 EUR, etc.).

title: Untitled
text: After the negative payout has been created on your Dashboard, you should expect the debits to take place as follows:

title: Untitled
text: For the best estimate as to when the funds will be debited from your bank account, you can check the ‘Expected by’ date of the payout on your Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: You may need to authorize Stripe to debit your US bank account. To do this, you will need to contact your bank directly and provide them with our ACH company IDs .

title: Untitled
text: Your bank may reject a payout if the bank account information entered on Stripe doesn't match what your bank has on file.

title: Untitled
text: Use the same name (either individual name or company name) from your bank statement when adding your bank account on Stripe. Ensure the bank account uses the same currency as the payout currency (for example, you are using a USD bank account to receive USD).

title: Untitled
text: You can sign up for a Stripe account via your preferred platform’s website or product. You can also sign up for Stripe and then connect your Stripe account to your platform.

title: Untitled
text: After you submit your application, for most businesses, the account approval process is nearly instantaneous and you will be able to accept payments right away. If Stripe needs more information about your business or expects a longer delay in approving your account, they will reach out to you immediately. Businesses on Stripe’s Restricted Business list commonly experience longer processing delays. If you are running a business that has trouble accepting payments online, we recommend reviewing Stripe’s Restricted Business documentation. If you’re not sure if your business falls into the categories listed here, reach out to Stripe Support.

title: Untitled
text: To sign up for an account, you’ll need an email address and password. To activate your account , Stripe will need details about your business and about you. Common follow-up requirements include photo identification documents and address verification. See a full list of requirements .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe offers a rich third-party ecosystem with hundreds of integrations ranging from tools for email alerts, shipping, taxes, and more. Explore Stripe integrations .

title: Untitled
text: As Stripe provides financial services, there are a number of restrictions that they have to operate under. Stripe has outlined these in their Services Agreement , which they’ve tried to make as readable as possible. You can also read more detail on these restrictions .

title: Untitled
text: See answers to common questions about using the Stripe Dashboard or learn more about the Stripe Dashboard in our docs .

title: Untitled
text: Try troubleshooting SMS two-step authentication , authenticate using a backup code , or remove two-step authentication from your account .

title: Untitled
text: The bank account on your Stripe account is being used for Stripe to send payouts to you. You can update your bank account on Stripe . You should also confirm whether you need to update your bank account information with your platform in addition to or in lieu of updating with Stripe.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe charges processing fee for each successful charge. This might differ in each country. You can learn more about pricing .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe allows you to accept a wide variety of payment types. Check with your platform to see which payment types are supported with your integration.

title: Untitled
text: With Stripe, you can accept payments from over 195 countries and over 135 currencies. Visit our partner directory , where you can filter partners by location.

title: Untitled
text: You can set a static statement descriptor or the shortened descriptor (prefix) in the Stripe Dashboard . This value then appears on all customer statements for charges or payments. You can also learn more about statement descriptors .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe offers you the ability to refund a customer charge, be it in full or a partial amount of the original charge. Learn more about refunds , including how to issue a refund from your Stripe Dashboard, how long refunds can take to reach your customers, and what to do if a refund is not received as expected.

title: Untitled
text: Reserved funds are used to prevent negative balances due to disputes and refunds. Most reserves Stripe places are temporary. There are a number of reasons that Stripe might place a reserve on an account. Read about some of the most common reasons .

title: Untitled
text: In addition to the reports offered by your platform, Stripe offers many reports in the Stripe Dashboard. Learn more about financial reports .

title: Untitled
text: For the second payout and onward, your standard payout timing depends on your sign-up country . For example, businesses in the US are paid out on a two-day rolling basis.

title: Untitled
text: You can also set a specific payout schedule from the Payouts settings page of your Stripe Dashboard. By default, your account is on an automatic everyday payout schedule.

title: Untitled
text: The first payout for every new Stripe account is made seven days after the first successful payment is received. This initial payout timing requirement cannot be waived. Any changes made to your payout timing or payout method during this time will take effect after this initial delay. This delay allows Stripe to mitigate some of the risk inherent in providing credit services. Learn more about payout schedules .

title: Untitled
text: Account verification issues are the most common causes of a delayed or paused payout. If your payouts are paused or delayed, Stripe will send you an email requesting further action. Alternatively, you can visit notifications (bell icon in the top right corner) in your Stripe Dashboard to see the action required.

title: Untitled
text: Your available Stripe balance may become negative if the cost of refunds or disputes is greater than the existing balance. Learn how to resolve negative balance .

title: Untitled
text: If your bank returns a payout, it may take several days to arrive at Stripe. Please contact Stripe Support to confirm payout status.

title: Untitled
text: If the bank account on your Stripe account is incorrect or closed, update your bank account information to avoid future failure. You should also confirm whether you need to update your bank account information with your platform in addition to or in lieu of updating with Stripe.

title: Untitled
text: If incorrect bank account details were added in your Stripe account, your payouts will have been sent to that bank account. If that bank account does not exist, the payout(s) will be returned to your Stripe balance.

title: Untitled
text: Instant Payouts allows a business to deposit their pending balance to their bank account within minutes. It’s available 24x7 on nights, weekends, and holidays.

title: Untitled
text: Instant Payouts is available to Stripe users in the US. New users to Stripe do not have access to Instant Payouts until sufficient payment history is established on the Stripe platform.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Radar is a suite of modern tools to help you fight fraud. It’s fully integrated into your payments flow and automatically works behind every Stripe transaction. At the center of Stripe Radar is a machine learning system that provides real-time transaction scoring based upon thousands of signals about each incoming card payment. Stripe’s system also uses data across their network of millions of businesses to evaluate the level of risk for each payment you process, and has shielded businesses on Stripe from millions of attempted fraudulent payments. Read more about Stripe Radar .

title: Untitled
text: What is fraud and how can I prevent it? What is a dispute or an inquiry and how do I handle them?

title: Untitled
text: Creating an effective dispute and fraud prevention strategy that best suits your business can help prevent fraud from occurring. By employing some of these best practices as part of your overall strategy, you can avoid excessive chargebacks and reduce potential customer burden and losses.

title: Untitled
text: Strong Customer Authentication (SCA) regulation in Europe requires the use of 3D Secure for card payments. Your platform can confirm if their integration with Stripe is already SCA-compliant and supports 3D Secure. Read Stripe’s Guides to 3D Secure and Strong Customer Authentication if you’d like to learn more.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Terminal lets businesses collect in-person payments. With one payment solution across channels, you can unify your online and offline payments, and simplify your reporting and reconciliation to save time and to improve business insights. Check with your platform to see if they offer Terminal.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Terminal supports the BBPOS Chipper 2X BT mobile reader and the Verifone P400 countertop reader. Check with your platform to see which version is supported by your integration. Learn more about these card readers .

title: Untitled
text: In-person payments must follow strict rules to meet PCI compliance, PCI certifications, and EMV certifications. Stripe Terminal offers pre-certified, PCI-compliant readers. This ensures that your transactions are secured by Stripe’s end-to-end encryption, and that your readers are always up to date via Stripe’s remote management tools.

title: Untitled
text: For the BBPOS Chipper 2X BT mobile reader: A single charge of the lithium polymer rechargeable battery supports 800 dips, 5000 swipes, or 1000 taps

title: Untitled
text: Charge the mobile card reader by attaching the included USB cord to an adapter and plugging it into a wall outlet.

title: Untitled
text: Any updates made to payout timing or method during this time will take effect after the waiting period. Check your estimated payout schedule at the Dashboard .

title: Untitled
text: Your first payout might take longer, depending on your industry risk level and country of operation. The waiting period can be up to 14 days for businesses in certain industries and up to 30 days in countries such as Brazil. See a full list of payout schedules by country .

title: Untitled
text: If you still haven’t received your payout after the designated waiting period see: Where is my payout? FAQ for missing and late payouts .

title: Untitled
text: If Stripe is not able to automatically verify your identity, Stripe may request additional documentation in order to verify the individuals connected to a Stripe account. Users in Europe, Canada, Australia, and New Zealand, will need to provide two separate documents :

title: Untitled
text: The information in these documents must match the information on your Stripe account. Confirm that the Stripe account personal information in your Dashboard is correct before documents are uploaded. Clicking Edit beside your personal details to make any changes.

title: Untitled
text: Both Proof of ID and Proof of Home Address document uploads must be successfully reviewed and matched to the information in your Stripe account before your identity can be verified. Reviews can take up to 24 hours.

title: Untitled
text: Due to the highly sensitive nature of your verification documents, Stripe can only accept documents which are uploaded through the Dashboard. Do not send documents by email.

title: Untitled
text: Our Privacy Policy explains how and for what purposes we collect, use, retain, disclose, and safeguard any personal data you provide to us.

title: Untitled
text: Before you create or connect a Stripe account to your partner platform, consider whether you need a single Stripe account for your business or multiple Stripe accounts. This video covers when you need more than one Stripe account and the benefits you gain from local acquiring if you’re planning to do business in more than a single country.

title: Untitled
text: If you're creating a Stripe account for the first time, it's helpful to know what Stripe needs to verify and activate your account. This information is required by regulators and helps prevent abuses in the financial system. Each country has its own set of regulations, and knowing beforehand what documentation you’ll need to submit during the account creation process will help you get online and open for business quickly and smoothly.

title: Untitled
text: Your Stripe Dashboard is the unified hub for your business on Stripe. In this video, we demonstrate key features of the Stripe Dashboard, including which authorized applications and platforms you’ve connected your account to, your account settings, account profile, and how to add users and roles to your account.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe support is available to all account holders 24 x 7 by email, chat, and phone.  Here’s a quick demo of our online support resources and how to reach out to the Stripe support team if you’re stuck.

title: Untitled
text: Here’s how to check our API status and how to configure your account to receive alerts to any system change that might affect your business, including our alert process, Twitter feed, blog, and changelogs. We also offer business guides and guides to keep you informed about the ever-evolving global payments landscape.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: If you accept credit cards on your site or store, you'll most likely have to handle chargebacks or inquiries. When a customer has an issue with a credit card charge, they can dispute it with their bank. The bank will initiate a dispute with either an inquiry or a chargeback. Learn what these terms mean, how they differ, and how banks and other payment systems initiate disputes.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: Disputes work differently across card and payment networks, but typically follow similar patterns. The dispute process involves multiple parties and many steps. This video walks you through each process and how and when you should submit evidence.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: Many inquiries and chargebacks are the result of the cardholder not recognizing the transaction or recognizing your business. This video outlines customer communication best practices and refund policy best practices.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: Early fraud warnings are notices generated to flag payments that are suspected to be fraudulent. An early fraud warning is created when a cardholder lodges a claim of fraud with their issuing bank and occurs before an official chargeback. This video shows you how to review early fraud warning in the Dashboard and respond effectively.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: In certain, comparatively rare, situations, Stripe may proactively refund a payment if you receive an early fraud warning on it. These situations include, but are not limited to, your business being domiciled in a high-dispute country, or your business trending toward being identified in a Card Monitoring Program (see next section).

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: As part of your financial obligations to the card networks, you must ensure that disputes and fraud are kept at acceptable levels. If these exceed the thresholds dictated by each network (for example, Visa or Mastercard), you’re placed into one of their monitoring programs. As part of a program, you can incur monthly fines and additional fees until you reduce your dispute or fraud levels.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: This video walks you through how card monitoring programs work and how Stripe can help you manage the process if your business is flagged in a monitoring program.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: Stripe Radar is a suite of modern tools to help you fight fraud. It’s fully integrated into your payments flow and you can start using it without any additional development time or cost. This video outlines Stripe Radar's features and benefits and how risk levels are communicated to you.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: Stripe's advanced fraud tool, Radar for Fraud Teams, is an add-on suite of tools for fraud professionals or any business experiencing high levels of risk. This video demonstrates how to use Radar for Fraud Teams in the Dashboard.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: Disputes fall into eight categories. There are different recommendations for how to respond to each category and what evidence you should provide based on the dispute reason. This video also introduces evidence labeled as "compelling evidence" and how to submit compelling evidence.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: When a customer opens a dispute with their bank (the issuing bank), the bank notifies Stripe and Stripe will notify you. As the merchant, you must prove certain evidence. This video gives you best practices for evidence submission.

title: An introduction to Fraud and Disputes
text: Learn how to test a dispute handling flow by creating a test mode dispute and responding to it in the Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe's financial reports help you with your accounting and reconciliation and understanding your account balance at every step of the payments lifecycle.

title: Untitled
text: Understanding how funds flow in and out of your Stripe account is an important part of processing payments. This video demonstrates where to find financial reports in the Stripe Dashboard and what each section of the reports represent, including balance reports and payout reconciliation reports. It also delineates how and when your financial data becomes available.

title: Untitled
text: The Stripe Dashboard includes filter and export options if you’re looking to download a CSV file of your payments transactions.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Sigma makes all your transactional data available as an interactive SQL environment right in your Stripe Dashboard. You can write custom queries or browse our collection of pre-configured reports that surface common questions and queries which you can use as a starting point for further analysis. Sigma allows you to view the query results directly in your browser, download them in CSV format for use in spreadsheets and other applications. You can also schedule and automate your reporting with scheduled queries.

title: Untitled
text: If you’re a business that uses Stripe through a partner platform, extension, or a plugin , this video how-to guide demonstrates the basics of creating a new Stripe account or connecting an existing account to your platform, how to verify the business information, and begin to manage your business on Stripe.

title: Untitled
text: Your platform will have specific instructions for how to connect with Stripe. This video demonstrates the steps you go through to create a new account or connect an existing Stripe account to your platform.

title: Untitled
text: Once you’ve created or connected an account, Stripe will verify your business information and approve your account, usually within a few minutes of submission. If we cannot verify your business information successfully, we’ll inform you both by email and in your Stripe Dashboard. This video demonstrates how to check your verification status and how to respond to further requests for information.

title: Untitled
text: This video demonstrates common account management tasks: changing your password, enabling two-factor authentication (2FA), setting your email preferences, updating your profile, and how to close an account.

title: Untitled
text: If you’re a business that uses Stripe through a partner platform, extension, or a plug-in , this video guide will help you understand payments and payouts in your Stripe account. In this section we’ll give you an overview of payments and payouts in Stripe. We’ll familiarize you with your payouts schedule, help you understand potential impacts to your schedule, and show you how to trace a payment all the way to your bank via the Stripe Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: Learn how to view all your customer transactions and the status of every payment on your account. Learn how to find specific transactions using Stripe’s default filters and how to create custom filters for your own needs. Finally, we demonstrate how to export transactions.

title: Untitled
text: With Stripe, you can accept payments in over 135 countries using a wide range of payment methods. Learn how currency conversion works on Stripe, how Stripe treats currency balances and payouts, and how to avoid unnecessary exchange fees when handling multiple currencies.

title: Untitled
text: In order to receive funds, Stripe (or your platform) makes payouts to your bank account. How quickly you receive a payout and the availability of your funds depends on numerous factors, including the industry, the country you’re operating in, and the risks and regulations that govern that industry and country. Learn how to find your payouts and payout status in the Dashboard and how to read payout details.

title: Untitled
text: Learn how to review and set your payout schedule, and how to choose between automatic payouts, manual payouts, and instant payouts.

title: Untitled
text: Learn how to troubleshoot payout failures and delays. In this video, we list the common reasons for payout failures and delays including account verification issues, funds being held in reserve, and bank routing issues.

title: Untitled
text: This page contains information intended for customers of businesses that use Stripe. If your business uses Stripe and you’d like to find out more about disputes, please see our article on the refund process .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe is unable to issue refunds on behalf of businesses using Stripe to accept payments. To initiate an exchange or refund, customers will need to reach out to the business directly.

title: Untitled
text: If you are unable to get in touch with the business or they are unresponsive, the next course of action would be to reach out to your bank for options. They may have recommendations for how to proceed, such as opening a dispute .

title: Dispute process
text: This page contains information intended for customers of businesses that use Stripe. If your business uses Stripe and you’d like to find out more about disputes, please see our article on the dispute process and submitting evidence .

title: Dispute process
text: Disputes, also known as chargebacks, are a feature of the Visa, Mastercard, and American Express card networks intended to protect you, the cardholder, from fraudulent activity (e.g., following a theft or card cloning). The dispute process can also be used to reverse authorized card payments in justified cases of breaches of consumer rights.

title: Dispute process
text: Before filing a dispute with your bank, it’s important that you exhaust any and all means of contacting the business you’re dealing with to resolve the issue amicably. If the business is unresponsive, or if you are not satisfied with their handling of your refund request, you can contact your bank to explore further options, including filing a dispute.

title: Dispute process
text: Note: The outcome of a dispute is decided upon entirely by your bank—Stripe has no involvement in this decision. To inquire about the status or outcome of a dispute, you will need to contact your bank.

title: What is Stripe?
text: This page contains information intended for customers of businesses that use Stripe. Please see the FAQ below if you have any questions about a charge or a merchant using Stripe

title: What is Stripe?
text: Stripe is payment service provider that millions of businesses of all sizes—from startups to large enterprises—use to accept payments, send payouts, and manage their businesses online.

title: What is Stripe?
text: Sometimes you might see a charge on your bank statement saying ‘STRIPE’. In most cases it is possible that you’ve purchased something from a business that uses Stripe to process their payments and the business name itself wasn’t reflected correctly on your bank statement.

title: What is Stripe?
text: If you notice an unknown charge saying “STRIPE” on your bank statement and you’re unsure which business has charged you, you can use our secure charge lookup tool to search for the business.

title: What is Stripe?
text: To initiate a refund , you will need to reach out to the business directly. Stripe is unable to issue refunds on behalf of businesses using Stripe to accept payments. Read more on Stripe's privacy practice on refunds .

title: What is Stripe?
text: If you are unable to get in touch with the business, they are unresponsive, or you believe the business might be fraudulent, the next course of action would be to reach out to your bank for next steps. They may have recommendations for how to proceed, such as opening a dispute .  Please note that Stripe is not authorized to issue a refund on behalf of the merchant.

title: What is Stripe?
text: If you believe you have been a victim of fraud, you should report the fraudulent charge and file a dispute with your bank. When you file a dispute, your bank passes all relevant details to Stripe, and we use this data in our ongoing effort to combat fraud.

title: What is Stripe?
text: If you have an issue with a purchase , wish to get an update on an order or haven't received it yet, we recommend that you first attempt to contact the merchant to resolve the matter directly. You can use the Charge Lookup Tool to find their contact details. If the merchant is unresponsive, we suggest you reach out to your bank. They may have recommendations for how to proceed, such as opening a dispute .

title: What is Stripe?
text: If you have a recurring subscription charge on your bank statement from a business using Stripe that you would like to cancel , you will need to reach out to the business directly. Stripe is not authorized to cancel subscriptions on behalf of customers.

title: What is Stripe?
text: When a card issuer creates a dispute on your behalf, the card network (Visa or Mastercard, for example) immediately debits Stripe for the disputed amount. From that point forward, it's up to the card issuer to decide when they return funds to their cardholder.

title: Untitled
text: This page contains information intended for customers of businesses that use Stripe. If your business uses Stripe and you’d like to find out more about subscriptions, please see our documentation .

title: Untitled
text: If you have a recurring subscription charge on your bank statement from Stripe or a business using Stripe that you would like to cancel or get refunded , you will need to reach out to the business. Stripe is not authorized to cancel subscriptions on behalf of customers of a business. If you are unable to get in touch with the business, they are unresponsive, or you believe the business might be fraudulent, the next course of action would be to reach out to your bank for options. They may have recommendations for how to proceed, such as opening a dispute .

title: Untitled
text: For context, Stripe is a payments processor that works with businesses to help them accept payments through their websites, apps, and in store.

title: Untitled
text: If you don’t know the business or how to get in touch, you can use our secure charge lookup tool to search for the business.

title: Untitled
text: Accepting a dispute signals that you do not intend to challenge it. On a technical level it is not very different from doing nothing and simply refraining from submitting evidence. Accepting a dispute might speed up the closure of the dispute from the cardholder perspective, but there is no guarantee of this, and no way to predict whether this will be the case with any given issuer.

title: Untitled
text: Operationally, accepting a dispute can be helpful to signal to yourself and other users on your account that you have already reviewed a dispute and made a decision to not challenge it.

title: Untitled
text: No. Accepting effectively speeds up the dispute being marked as lost, but is otherwise no different from any other lost dispute.

title: Untitled
text: It might, but you shouldn't assume that it will. In any dispute, the question of when funds are returned to the cardholder is up to the card issuer and their own handling of the dispute process.

title: Untitled
text: Whether you accept the dispute or challenge it and lose, it's up to the issuer to decide when they will return funds to their cardholder. Your acceptance may or may not influence this.

title: Untitled
text: Yes. From the card network perspective, an accepted dispute is just like any other dispute, and still counts against your dispute rate . The dispute is not erased or annulled in any way.

title: Untitled
text: A dispute (also known as a chargeback) occurs when a cardholder questions your payment with their card issuer.  The dispute process and timeline varies by card network, but typically follows this process .

title: Untitled
text: Every new dispute is assigned a reason code . If you believe the dispute's reason is incorrect or want to challenge the dispute, upload evidence supporting why the payment was valid through the Dashboard or via the API . Stripe sends submitted evidence to the card issuer for their review.

title: Untitled
text: Disputes are decided entirely by the entity who issued the cardholder's card. In some cases that's the card network itself (as with American Express) and in some cases that's an issuing bank (as with Mastercard or Visa).

title: Untitled
text: The card network (such as Visa, Mastercard, or American Express) defines the dispute process -- the "rules of the road" for how disputes work. The issuer decides whether any given dispute is won or lost. In some cases (as with American Express) these are the same entity.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe facilitates your participation in the dispute process by helping you select the best possible evidence for the dispute reason in the dashboard, and transmitting your evidence to the card network, but Stripe does not make any decision about your dispute.

title: Untitled
text: No. The issuer's decision is final and cannot be appealed or challenged. Some card networks feature a dispute lifecycle phase called "arbitration" in which a loss can be appealed (for a substantial card network fee), but Stripe does not currently support this.

title: Untitled
text: It may still be possible to have your customer withdraw the dispute, even after the dispute is closed. You can read more about withdrawn disputes here:

title: Untitled
text: Whether you win or lose a dispute makes no difference. It is the dispute itself that is counted by the card networks in your dispute metrics. The outcome of the dispute doesn't affect that. You can read more about how disputes are measured here:

title: Untitled
text: A dispute (also known as a chargeback) occurs when a cardholder questions your payment with their card issuer. The card issuer creates a formal dispute which immediately reverses the payment. Stripe notifies you of the dispute and debits your Stripe balance for the dispute amount plus a dispute received fee. If you choose to counter the dispute, a dispute countered fee applies (excluding businesses in Mexico and Japan), in addition to the dispute received fee. If you win the dispute, the dispute countered fee is returned to you.

title: Untitled
text: The disputed amount and dispute received fee will appear in your balance history as a single balance transaction. The dispute countered fee will appear as a separate transaction.

title: Untitled
text: If you issue a full refund on a charge before a dispute happens, the cardholder can’t dispute it. In this case, you’re protected from a future dispute or dispute received fee.

title: Untitled
text: The fee is also incurred on evidence uploaded by you and auto-submitted before the deadline by Stripe. You can turn off auto-submission on the Dispute settings page.

title: Untitled
text: You can see the fee in the Dashboard. From the Disputes page, navigate to the Payment Detail page by clicking a dispute and find the Dispute countered fee under Fees in the Payment Breakdown .

title: Untitled
text: The dispute countered fee is applied directly to your account balance via a balance transfer. The fee is not shown in the balance_transactions field of the Dispute API object.

title: Untitled
text: To calculate the total amount charged for dispute countered fees, you can use the Stripe API to identify disputes that were charged the fee. We recommend setting up a webhook to listen to dispute closed events to determine if the dispute incurred the fee. See below for an example webhook in Ruby:

title: Untitled
text: Multiply the number of disputes that incurred the fee by the dispute countered fee sticker price , or the price in your pricing agreement if you have negotiated pricing.

title: Untitled
text: If a lost dispute is overturned by the card network or issuing bank we will return the dispute countered fee to you. Set up a webhook to listen to dispute funds reinstated events .

title: Untitled
text: Every card network has some provision in its dispute system for the cardholder to retract a dispute after filing it. If you can settle the matter amicably with your customer, and convince them to withdraw the dispute, that’s the most effective way to win it.

title: Untitled
text: Yes. Some card issuers will treat failure to submit evidence as an acceptance of liability. To be safe, you should always submit evidence contesting the reason for the dispute .

title: Untitled
text: In most cases, yes. If you submitted evidence before the deadline, and the customer withdrew the dispute while it was still open, the card issuer should eventually return a win result on that dispute.

title: Untitled
text: If you did not submit evidence, or if the customer attempted to withdraw the dispute after it was closed or otherwise outside the dispute lifecycle timeline, the dispute might not be reversed.

title: Untitled
text: As far as the card networks (like Mastercard or Visa) are concerned, it should be technically possible for a cardholder to withdraw a dispute at any time. However individual card issuers within that network may or may not support withdrawing disputes once they have been closed.

title: Untitled
text: Yes. As with any other kind of dispute, you can ask your customer to withdraw and they should be able to get their issuer to cancel the dispute. But be aware that in the case of a fraud dispute, there's an excellent chance the person you're dealing with as your customer is not the actual cardholder.

title: Untitled
text: It is not required that you gather proof of withdrawal from your customer, or that you provide this proof in your evidence (although you should always submit some evidence contesting the reason for the dispute ).

title: Untitled
text: Gathering this proof might provide peace of mind that your customer actually did withdraw the dispute, and submitting it with your evidence may make it easier for the card issuer's evidence reviewer to track down and verify the dispute was actually withdrawn, but it is not an explicit part of the dispute process.

title: Untitled
text: A withdrawn dispute is no different from any other dispute and in general card issuers will still follow the normal dispute timeline . You should expect a withdrawn dispute to turn into a win on the same timeline as a dispute that you win by arguing your case in evidence. The full lifecycle of a dispute, from initiation to the final decision from the issuer, can take as long as 2-3 months to complete.

title: Untitled
text: You cannot issue refunds on a charge on which there is a dispute pending decision from the issuer. Once the issuer returns a win decision (which happens along the normal dispute timeline), your ability to refund the charge returns.

title: Untitled
text: Yes. From the card network perspective, a withdrawn dispute is just a won dispute, and won disputes still count against your dispute rate . The dispute is not erased or annulled in any way.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Apps has an integration with third party app providers listed below to help you with dispute management and chargeback protection.

title: Untitled
text: ChargebackStop - We collaborate with issuers and card networks to address customer disputes and fraud events through the Ethoca and Verifi Network, proactively refunding payments before the chargeback is filed to avoid it completely.

title: Untitled
text: Chargeblast - Receive dispute alerts via emails before a transaction officially turns into a chargeback. You have 24 – 48 hours to refund the transaction before it becomes a dispute. You can refund these transactions via Stripe though links to the corresponding transaction from the Chargeblast dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: Chargeflow - Streamline your business operations with a fully automated chargeback management system. Uses AI/ML-based automation technology resolve chargebacks for you.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Apps allow you to connect Stripe with your help desk, accounting software, and more so that you can simplify workflows and add context in Stripe to give you a holistic view of your business.

title: Untitled
text: Chargeback - Chargeback detects when a customer initiates a chargeback with their bank. Once an incoming dispute has been detected, Chargeback gives you an alert. The alert enables you to automatically refund transactions before turning into chargebacks. Significantly reducing your chargeback rate and maintaining a healthy merchant account.

title: Untitled
text: The Visa Compelling Evidence 3.0 (CE 3.0) update introduces new rules that help merchants combat first-party misuse (friendly fraud) by weighting a cardholder’s non-fraud prior transactions with the merchant as evidence of likely legitimacy of the disputed transaction.

title: Untitled
text: Disputes with Visa reason code 10.4 (Card absent fraud) are eligible to submit prior non-fraud transaction history as evidence of current transaction legitimacy. Qualifying prior transactions must fall within 120 – 365 calendar days prior to the disputed transaction processing date.

title: Untitled
text: The new rules dictate that if a clear link between the merchant and the cardholder can be identified, the issuing bank is much more likely to rule the dispute in favor of the business. Visa’s qualifying criteria to demonstrate the link is as follows:

title: Untitled
text: For all disputes with Visa reason code 10.4, merchants can increase their odds of winning by providing two prior transactions with the same cardholder where:

title: Untitled
text: Stripe does this for you. Upon receiving a qualifying dispute, Stripe automatically queries your past transaction history to identify if you have two prior transactions that meet the criteria. If you do, Stripe reflects the eligibility in the dispute notification email and in a banner on the dispute’s details page in the Dashboard, encouraging you to counter the dispute.

title: Untitled
text: Throughout the evidence submission form, we’ve identified the relevant fields required for the CE 3.0 program with the Required for Visa CE 3.0 badge and auto-filled many of them on your behalf. You must provide the correct information for any empty required fields, but you needn’t edit any auto-filled responses because it might affect the eligibility of the transactions we’ve matched for you. We don’t expose every CE 3.0 relevant field, such as customer email address and shipping address, in the evidence collection form, but we do make sure every evidence response includes all required data.

title: Untitled
text: NOTE: To increase the odds of Stripe identifying prior transactions with the appropriate fields, consider updating your Stripe integration to increase the incidence with which you share CE 3.0 qualifying data, like IP address, customer email, and shipping address.

title: Untitled
text: Submitting evidence under CE 3.0 guidelines does not guarantee an auto-win, issuing banks still have discretion as to wether a dispute is ruled in favor of a merchant. If you do not fill in all fields that are labelled as required for CE 3.0 in the Stripe dashboard, it will no longer be eligible. In rare cases, issuers will send a delayed TC40 (fraud report) on the prior transactions used as evidence. This disqualifies them from being used as evidence under CE 3.0 and can cause issuers to reject the dispute.

title: I got an error message that my evidence files exceed the total size limit (5 MB). What should I do?
text: If you received the error message “The file you uploaded was too large. Please upload a file smaller than 5 MB” while trying to upload a PDF for Dispute evidence, try the following steps to reduce the file size:

title: I got an error message that my evidence files exceed the total size limit (5 MB). What should I do?
text: If the file you are uploading is one of the above accepted formats, and you are still presented with this error, you may need to perform the set of troubleshooting steps outlined by the above question (I’m trying to upload evidence as a PDF - how can I reduce the file size?).

title: I got an error message that my evidence files exceed the total size limit (5 MB). What should I do?
text: Please convert your image to a PDF or JPEG, then retry the upload. There are many free ways to do this conversion, but we recommend using this free tool from Adobe .

title: I got an error message that my evidence files exceed the total size limit (5 MB). What should I do?
text: The file you are trying to upload is a PDF Portfolio. A PDF Portfolio contains multiple files assembled into an integrated PDF unit.

title: I got an error message that my evidence files exceed the total size limit (5 MB). What should I do?
text: Please combine the documents within the PDF Portfolio into a single PDF File. To do this, you will need a recent version of Adobe Acrobat , and will have to obtain one if you do not have it (though other PDF applications may also have this capability).

title: Untitled
text: The following table explains the information included on a 1099-K form. Download a blank example 1099-K form and learn more about your 1099-K on IRS.gov .

title: Untitled
text: Either your Employer Identification Number (EIN), Social Security Number (SSN), or Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) as it was provided to Stripe. For your protection, the form that we send you might show only the last four digits. Copies that are sent to the IRS and state tax boards include your complete identification number. If your information needs to be updated and:

title: Untitled
text: For accounts that are set up as US Companies, Stripe will use the business tax details except when the account is set up as a Single Member LLC / Sole Proprietorship , in which case we’ll use the owner’s personal tax details .

title: Untitled
text: This is because these account types are considered disregarded entities by the IRS for income tax purposes. For Individuals, Stripe will use the personal tax details. For additional information, please see the IRS website .

title: Untitled
text: You can export a list of all payment transactions for a specified year from your Dashboard using the Available On filter. The Amount column for these list of transactions will provide a complete summary of all transactions that contributed towards the totals used to determine your eligibility in receiving a 1099-K form . If you did not qualify for a 1099-k, you can use this report to see why.

title: Untitled
text: 1099-Ks from Stripe to Connect Custom and Express platforms will also include all transactions processed through their connected accounts. See 1099-K Platforms for more information.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe delivers 1099-K forms directly in your Dashboard by January 31. These tax forms are filed with the IRS and various state taxing authorities between January to April, per filing requirements.

title: Untitled
text: Note: If the address, name and / or TIN format entered is incorrect and cannot be verified against the details on file with the IRS, the IRS will likely reject the new submission to update or correct the form. Contact Stripe Support for assistance if this occurs.

title: Untitled
text: Only the Name, Address and TIN (SSN or EIN) can be updated on a 1099 tax form. Stripe is required to report total gross volume; thus, Stripe cannot change amounts on 1099 forms. Per IRS regulations, both full and partial refunds are not deducted from the gross volume .

title: Untitled
text: If there are concerns about the amounts that appear on your 1099 tax form, you can reconcile the amounts and transactions which contributed to the 1099 tax form total.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe cannot directly assist in this process; consult your accountant or tax advisor for help. Learn how to calculate fees, refunds and adjustments .

title: Untitled
text: A split 1099 tax form allows apportioning the reported volume between two or more legal entities for the same tax year. This cannot be done before filing and can only be completed once a 1099 has been filed with the IRS, typically near the end of March.

title: Untitled
text: If your 1099 was issued to your personal SSN instead of your business EIN (or vice versa), you may need to update the business type on your account. The business type selected during account set up affects the tax reporting process.

title: Untitled
text: Individual business types (e.g., Sole Proprietorship) will always issue 1099 tax forms to the primary account representative credentials (Name + SSN).

title: Untitled
text: Company business types (e.g., Corporation, Non-Profit, etc.) will always issue 1099 tax forms to the business legal entity (LE Name + EIN).

title: Untitled
text: Correcting your tax form does not change your business type or structure. Similarly, updating your business type or structure in the Settings > Tax Details section in the Dashboard will not automatically correct tax forms if they have already been filed.

title: Untitled
text: The 1099 corrections process involves filing multiple sequential forms with the IRS. In your documents panel , you will see three forms for each tax year in which you’ve filed a correction.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe cannot zero out or nullify a tax form without having a new legal entity to attribute the volume to. Stripe is required by federal law to report all eligible processing volume.

title: Untitled
text: Any changes made to taxpayer details used for the 1099 form (e.g., Name, Address, TIN) before filing , are considered updates. This includes changes made directly to the forms via your dashboard , or updates made to your account’s legal entity . Any updates made to name, address, or TIN on your account during this time will automatically update your pending 1099 tax forms.

title: Untitled
text: After filing with federal and/or state tax authorities, changes to taxpayer details for 1099 forms will require a correction . Any updates made to your taxpayer details on your account will not automatically correct your tax forms after filing.

title: Untitled
text: This article is neither legal advice nor tax advice. We recommend that you speak to your tax advisor with any questions or concerns around tax reporting.

title: Untitled
text: For tax year 2023 and later, you can use the Stripe Dashboard to export the transaction log for each 1099 form. This transaction log lists the Stripe transactions that contribute to the form's total, allowing you to audit discrepancies and clarify which transactions are included in the tax form.

title: Untitled
text: After exporting the transaction log, the sum of its Total Gross Volume column reflects the form total reported on your 1099-K form. We provide details for each transaction including the applicable account_id , payment_id , available_on_date , and the total gross volume relevant to that transaction.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe uses the available_on date of the balance transaction associated with the payment to determine which tax year the transaction belongs to. The available_on date represents the date the funds become available in the Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe’s 1099 calculation methods convert non-USD transactions to USD using the market exchange rate from the day the transaction is created. This method might yield a different value than the Stripe Dashboard shows because we compute that value using an intra-day exchange rate adjusted for Stripe’s foreign exchange fee .

title: Untitled
text: Due to rounding differences, you may find a difference between the total calculated from the transaction log and the total reported on your 1099-K form. Each transaction could only differ by a maximum of 1 cent, but when conducting a high volume of transactions throughout the year, this discrepancy may accumulate and become more noticeable.

title: Untitled
text: Transaction logs only contain Stripe transactions. Manual updates through CSV imports or the Dashboard’s Tax form editor won’t be included in the transaction log.

title: Untitled
text: The transaction log file will be ready for download after Stripe completes the export process. If you selected the email notification option, you will also receive an email from notification@stripe.com containing a link to download your transaction log.

title: Untitled
text: To reconcile your 1099-K form for all tax years prior to tax year 2023, contact Support to get the reconciliation report for your 1099-K form for a given tax year.

title: Untitled
text: If you did not receive a 1099-K and need to reconcile, see How can I review all my payment transactions for the tax year? .

title: Untitled
text: For platforms working on 1099 tax forms for connected accounts, see Stripe Documentation . For Express or Custom connected accounts, see Express Support Site .

title: Untitled
text: The 1099-K form is a purely informational document that summarizes the sales activity of your account. It is designed to assist you in reporting your taxes. For more information on what is included on your 1099-K form, see Information included on a 1099-K form .

title: Untitled
text: Every year, the United States’ IRS and certain states requires that Stripe provide a 1099-K for each Stripe account that meets all of the following criteria in the previous calendar year:

title: Untitled
text: Stripe issues 1099-K forms to all eligible U.S.-based users who accept payments, regardless of their business type or activity. The 1099-K is provided to both the account holder and the IRS, as well as some U.S. states.

title: Untitled
text: State filing requirements might differ from federal requirements. View the full list of state filing thresholds in this table .

title: Untitled
text: Prior to calendar year 2024, the 1099-K threshold applied to accounts based in the U.S. and having $20,000 USD in total gross volume and 200 transactions.

title: Untitled
text: If your business qualifies for a 1099-K, your 1099-K for the previous calendar year will be available to download from the Documents section of the Dashboard by January 31st . We notify account admins via email when the form is available.

title: Untitled
text: If you didn't qualify for a 1099-K and would like to see your payment transaction history for the previous year, see How can I review all my payment transactions for the tax year? .

title: Untitled
text: You can export your 1099-K forms from the Documents section of the Dashboard . You can download any available 1099-K PDF that we have prepared for you.

title: Untitled
text: If you no longer have access to your Stripe account, Stripe will mail the 1099-K using the latest address information that you’ve provided.

title: Untitled
text: If your 1099-K includes incorrect tax details, you can update these details from the Documents section of the Dashboard .

title: Untitled
text: If you need to split the volume of your generated 1099-K form between two separate legal entities, contact Stripe Support .

title: Untitled
text: If you believe the amount in box 1a is incorrect, see the section below on understanding the total reported volume.

title: Untitled
text: These additional fees, refunds, and adjustments are not deducted from your total charges when calculating your gross volume and reporting to the IRS. Stripe must report total gross volume and cannot update amounts on 1099 tax forms.

title: Untitled

This means 1099-Ks from Stripe to Connect Custom and Express platforms report the full volume to the US platform on the 1099-K.

title: Untitled
text: A 1099-K is only informational. It is not a statement of revenue or income, and should not result in any additional tax being owed.
