text: In order to use your existing SEPA DD customer information with the newer APIs, you will need to complete a data migration to convert your reusable Sources to PaymentMethods. To do so, see our article on migrating reusable objects from Sources to Payment Intents.

title: Untitled
text: If you are a WooCommerce user that is hitting this error, you will need to recollect your customer’s SEPA DD information. We recognize that this is not ideal and we are working with the WooCommerce team on improvements.

title: Additional Information
text: However, if you would like to use your own creditor identifier, you can request a SEPA creditor identifier from a financial institution in the country in which you have your main office or residence -- commonly this is the bank with which you hold your account.

title: Additional Information
text: When contacting your bank for your SEPA creditor identifier, make sure to clarify that you are not requesting that they process SEPA Direct Debit payments for you, but that you are asking for your creditor ID number.

title: Additional Information
text: SEPA Direct Debit provides a dispute process for bank account holders to dispute payments. For a period of eight weeks after their account was debited, an account holder can dispute a payment through their bank on a “no questions asked” basis. Any disputes within this period are automatically honored. This is a feature of SEPA Direct Debit as a payment method, and Stripe has no control here.

title: Additional Information
text: A dispute can also occur if the customer’s bank is unable to debit their account because of a problem (e.g., the account is frozen or has insufficient funds), but it has already provided the funds to make a charge successful. In this instance, the bank reclaims those funds in the form of a dispute.

title: Additional Information
text: Unlike credit card disputes, all SEPA Direct Debit disputes are final and there is no appeals process. If a customer successfully disputes a payment, you must reach out to them if you would like to resolve the situation.

title: FAQ
text: Card merchants (Stripe users) in Japan are expected to implement a certain level of security measures under the Installment Sales Act. Due to incidents involving unauthorized use of card data, the Credit Card Transactions Security Measures Council , an industry body, has published a “Security Checklist” that outlines specific measures that Japan merchants who process online card transactions must implement.

title: FAQ
text: Stripe and other payment service providers (PSPs) are required to collect a declaration from new card merchants regarding their adoption of the security measures. Subject users will see this surfaced as questions before they complete onboarding. The questions will outline the measures required, and if users are deemed to have insufficient security measures in accordance with the questions, they will not be able to process card payments.

title: FAQ
text: To learn more, please refer to the " Security Checklist - Basic Security Measures for Online Merchants " published by the Credit Card Transactions Security Measures Council (available in Japanese).

title: FAQ
text: You may answer questions based on the measures you intend to have at the time you start processing card payments. However, if you submit the form before completing the adoption of any measures, you are expected to refrain from accepting card transactions until the work is complete.

title: FAQ
text: If you only accept payments through Payment Links or Stripe Invoicing and do not sell your goods and services through an online website, you are only required to answer some of the questions.

title: FAQ
text: Implementation will differ depending on how you process payments and design your website. If you use plug-ins or outsource your system architecture to a third party, please ask them for support in answering the questions. If you will develop the measures on your own, you can find further details in this Implementation Guide circulated by the Credit Card Transactions Security Measures Council (available in Japanese).

title: FAQ
text: If you plan to address the security measures through outsourcing, please answer based on information from your third party providers. You are still responsible for answering the questions.

title: FAQ
text: Please make sure to include information regarding the outsourcing party and/or the Application Source Provider you use. Outsourcing party information is necessary if a third party is involved in operating your website and/or in being responsible for security measures you adopt.

title: FAQ
text: Stripe and other PSPs are required to collect answers from every new user that will process card payments. While we cannot answer the questions for you, we have provided some guidance and suggestions when we think our products can be used to address the security measures.

title: FAQ
text: Stripe will automatically limit the number of times the validity of a card can be tested, based on a range of factors and data. Therefore, for payments processed by Stripe, you can respond that you implement at least one of the security measures listed to combat malicious card testing (5. Card testing countermeasures). Learn more about additional measures you can adopt to protect yourself from card testing here .

title: FAQ
text: We are not collecting responses from existing Stripe accounts now. We are monitoring developments and will provide updates if and when responses become necessary from existing accounts.

title: FAQ
text: Stripe and other PSPs are required to collect answers from every new user that will process card payments. The Security Checklist and related questions are aimed to ensure online card transactions are kept safe and secure. This is an industry-wide requirement and is not an initiative specific to Stripe.

title: FAQ
text: We generally do not accept changes once the answers are submitted. If you need time to determine which measures you will adopt, please wait until you have the necessary information to submit your answers. If you submit answers based on the measures you intend to adopt later, please not accept online card payments until you have completed adopting those measures.

title: FAQ
text: In general, we expect users to comply with the Security Checklist requirements by adopting the measures listed. However, we may be able to recognize certain alternative measures if they have at least the same degree of effectiveness. If you rely on an alternative security measure that is not listed in the response options and/or the Security Checklist, please contact support with an explanation of what measure you have adopted, why you believe it is an adequate alternative, and which requirement you think it addresses.

title: FAQ
text: For more information, you may also refer to the " Security Checklist - Basic Security Measures for Online Merchants ".

title: Additional Information
text: Stripe Terminal is a complete solution for in-person payments, and we can help you get started with migrating your existing card-present system. If you are interested in migrating, contact us .

title: Untitled
text: If you want to use Stripe Terminal in your country, let us know . We’ll notify you when we’re able to offer Terminal where you are.

title: Untitled
text: Readers must be physically located in the country of the Stripe account. For Connect platforms where the connected account is the settlement merchant, the readers must be physically located in the country of the connected account.

title: Untitled
text: Payments must be processed in the local currency. Stripe Terminal does not support multi-currency presentment or dynamic currency conversion (DCC).

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Terminal only works with our pre-certified card readers and Tap to Pay on iPhone . This ensures that transactions are secured by our end-to-end encryption and that your readers are always up-to-date via our remote management tools.

title: Untitled
text: Most Australian-issued debit payment cards display two debit payment networks – eftpos (eftpos Payments Australia Limited) and another card network (for example, Mastercard debit, Visa debit). Payments using a card displaying two debit payment networks may be processed through either network, regardless of the logo displayed when a customer enters their payment information.

title: Untitled
text: As part of its Conclusions to the Review of Retail Payments Regulation in October 2021 , the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) expects all acquirers, payment facilitators, and gateways to offer and promote least-cost routing functionality (LCR, also called merchant-choice routing) to Australian merchants in both device-present (in-person) and device-not-present (online) environments.

title: Untitled
text: LCR occurs when a customer makes a payment with their dual-network debit card and the transaction is deliberately routed to particular debit networks rather than letting all transactions flow to the default network as set by card issuers or card schemes. The choice of debit network may be based on several different factors, such as which network is the lowest cost to accept, or whether the merchant has a particular network preference.

title: Untitled
text: Transactions made using eftpos dual-network debit cards will generally route through eftpos (based on lowest average costs), provided that the transaction type can be supported by eftpos.

title: Untitled
text: For online environments, we recommend that you inform your customers that whenever they use a dual-network debit card, payments may be processed through either debit network. For guidelines on best practice, refer to our eftpos online documentation.

title: Untitled
text: If you’d like to opt-out of least-cost routing, and require that eftpos is never the default network for any payments,  contact support .

title: Untitled
text: While Stripe endeavors to route such transactions through eftpos, other factors may impact which network a transaction is routed through, including: (1) technical availability, and (2) authorization rate considerations. Changes in the network that route these transactions may result in changes to merchant transaction costs. For further information, refer to the “integration” sections of our in-person and online eftpos documentation.

title: Untitled
text: Least-cost routing is supported on Tap to Pay on Android in Australia. While the local debit network is supported on Tap to Pay on iPhone, least-cost routing isn't supported.

title: Untitled
text: Adding the Link Payment Method to your checkout page auto-fills your customers’ payment and shipping information to enable faster checkouts. If your customer has saved a dual-network debit card to their Link account, the payment may be processed through either network in the same way as if your customer chooses to input their card details at checkout.

title: Untitled
text: If you're interested in offering customized pay-over-time options to buyers, enable Affirm in the Buy Now, Pay Later Payment Methods section of your Stripe Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: Payments made via this QR code method require the terminal to have a functional network connection (offline mode is not supported for QR code payments). To test this flow, you can use a physical reader in your sandbox environment. Scanning the QR code will lead to an Affirm-hosted sandbox page or a Stripe-hosted test page to simulate the transaction.

title: Untitled
text: For more details on the customer experience and to promote Affirm in your store, refer to Affirm's training resources . This QR code method is designed for a more direct integration with Affirm. Unlike the virtual card option below, using Affirm branding and discussing Affirm in your store is generally part of this integrated experience, subject to your agreement with Affirm and Stripe.

title: Untitled
text: Affirm Anywhere allows customers to shop by generating a single-use virtual card in the Affirm app that can be used at any eligible merchant’s business. As long as you do not sell products or services listed in Affirm's Prohibited Business Polic y , consumers can use Affirm virtual cards at your business. Cardholders load the Affirm card into their mobile wallets and check out without any integration work required from you.

title: Untitled
text: With this path, you won’t have a relationship with Affirm, and you cannot use Affirm branding or discuss Affirm in your store. The virtual card will be processed like a normal Visa credit card or debit card, and interchange or similar debit or credit processing fees will apply.

title: Untitled
text: Afterpay/Clearpay are supported on Stripe Terminal via their virtual, contactless cards, which customers add to Apple Pay or Google Pay. The QR code payment method described for Affirm is not available for Afterpay/Clearpay.

title: Untitled
text: Once you've completed signing up for an Afterpay Merchant account, you will receive an email with the title “Afterpay Card is ready for you to set up” with instructions on completing a test transaction. The transaction details will provide Afterpay with all the information about your business that they need.

title: Untitled
text: If your business has multiple locations, or if you don't want to do the test transaction, you will need to submit the following information: Store name, Address, Afterpay Merchant ID, Scheme name, Acquirer MID. You can obtain the Scheme name and Acquirer MID directly from Stripe:

title: Untitled
text: Then respond to the automated email titled “Afterpay Card is ready for you to set up” with all of the above information.

title: Untitled
text: If customers start experiencing in-person declines when using their Afterpay Card, please check that your MID is still enabled correctly. You can use this Formstack if you have any issues after onboarding, or if you’d like to update or expand your setup. For individual declines, please refer your customers to Afterpay’s in-app Help for further troubleshooting.

title: Untitled
text: If you agree to the applicable Klarna terms and conditions, you’ll be granted access to Klarna’s “Merchant Portal”. Follow Klarna’s instructions, which may include a request to upload your brand assets, including a feature image, brand logo, and icon within the portal.

title: Untitled
text: Klarna will request (via email) store location details in order to unlock your terminals. Details requested may include the following:

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Terminal smart readers (including the Stripe Reader S700 and the BBPOS WisePOS E) surface error codes if it’s having difficulty updating the device. If you come across these intermittently, try leveraging the ethernet dock ( S700 , WisePOS E ) to root cause if it’s WiFi or other factors.

title: Untitled
text: You can also try pinging aws.com from another device on the network to see if you’re experiencing any packet loss in general.

title: Additional information
text: This doesn't apply if you're using our mobile readers (Wisepad3, Stripe reader M2), or using our server-driven integration with our smart readers (WisePOS E, S700).

title: Additional information
text: Additionally, allow all Stripe domains within your firewall settings. If you're prompted with Set Network Location on a Windows computer, select the Work option. Selecting Home will block the network connections required for Stripe Terminal to function.

title: Untitled
text: If you're using an older system platform with the Stripe Terminal SDK and having connection issues with your Internet Reader (WisePOS E, S700), make sure your system has the ISRG Root X1 root certificate installed.

title: Untitled
text: Some DNS providers block DNS resolution of local IP addresses. You can check whether DNS resolution is successful by going to the settings on your reader and selecting Diagnostics , and checking the DNS resolution test results. Stripe Terminal uses the partially qualified domain name *.[random-string].device.stripe-terminal-local-reader.net , which resolves to the local IP address of your BBPOS WisePOS E or S700. If your DNS provider blocks local IP resolution, change your network settings to use one of the following DNS providers:

title: Untitled
text: This only impacts the Stripe Terminal JavaScript SDK, so if you are using the server-driven integration or any of our mobile SDKs (Android, iOS, React Native) to communicate with our smart readers, this will not impact you.

title: Untitled
text: If you have access to your router settings, we recommend making this change on your router at the location where you are accepting in-person payments. This way, all devices at that location will receive the correct DNS configuration.

title: Untitled
text: If you have more than one smart readers, you may prefer to modify the DNS of your WiFi on your network router to avoid changing the DNS settings on each point of sale. There should be no impact on any of your regular internet traffic by changing the router's DNS to any well-known providers listed above.

title: Untitled
text: If you are using a Windows machine as your point of sale, follow the steps listed here or here to change DNS settings. Note: You may need device administrator permissions to modify DNS settings. You will need to change the DNS on each Windows machine used with Stripe Terminal.

title: Untitled
text: If you are using a Mac, follow these steps to change your point of sale DNS settings in macOS. If you are using an iPad, follow these steps . You may need device admin permissions to modify the DNS. You'll need to change the DNS on each Apple device you are using as a point of sale.

title: Untitled
text: Most modern browsers such as Google Chrome or Firefox support modifying the DNS in use directly in the browser by using DNS over HTTPS. See detailed instructions on modifying the DNS your browser uses.

title: Untitled
text: Apple Safari currently does not support DNS over HTTPS, therefore any DNS changes have to be performed on the device itself.

title: Understanding tamper
text: A tampered payment reader device may be compromised and should not be used for payment transaction as it could pose a data security risk.

title: Understanding tamper
text: If your terminal reader detects a possible security breach, it will display a tampered message. If you see this message, immediately discontinue using the device for payment processing and contact Stripe or your platform. The terminal reader will need replacement to ensure transaction security.

title: Understanding tamper
text: If you see on-screen messages like those shown on the BBPOS WisePOS E or Stripe Reader S700, your device has detected a tamper and entered a tampered state.

title: Untitled
text: You can block transactions from Mastercard debit and/or Visa debit cards by creating a custom block rule in Stripe Radar .

title: Untitled
text: Mastercard debit cards: Block if :card_funding: = 'debit' and :card_brand: = 'mc' and :card_country: = 'CA' Visa debit cards: Block if :card_funding: = 'debit' and :card_brand: = 'visa' and :card_country: = 'CA'

title: Untitled
text: Note that the above rules block cards based on their card_brand as well as the card_country attributes, which is represented as the two-letter ISO country code for this country. In this case, CA is for Canada.

title: Untitled
text: The “Request 3D Secure if 3D Secure is required” rule is deprecated. If this rule is still active on your account, it will no longer match any payments.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe now automatically handles 3DS requirements more accurately through direct processing of soft decline responses from card issuers and built-in compliance with regulatory requirements (such as Strong Customer Authentication under PSD2). This approach is more precise than the legacy rule, which sometimes requested 3DS authentication even when it wasn’t required.

title: Untitled
text: No action is required. Stripe will continue to automatically request 3DS authentication whenever it’s required by the issuing bank or necessary for regulatory compliance.

title: Untitled
text: By default, Radar doesn’t scan if you set up a Payment Method for future use without a charge. Because of this, Stripe  allows for Radar and Radar for Fraud Teams to be enabled for SetupIntents . Request 3DS, Allow Rules, and Block rules can be evaluated against Setup Intents, however Radar for Setup Intents does not support Review rules.

title: Untitled
text: To enable Radar for SetupIntents, go to the Radar settings in your Dashboard and toggle Use Radar on payment methods saved for future use . This applies Radar rules to payment methods created using the Setup Intents API . You will be charged per SetupIntent confirmation attempt, including SetupIntents generated by Subscriptions created with non-payment invoices .

title: Untitled
text: Prior to November 2024, the default Radar rules Block if CVC verification fails and Block if postal code verification fails were evaluated for all Setup Intents, regardless of a user’s Radar settings. This behavior was inconsistent with evaluation of other Radar rules, which are only triggered for Setup Intents if a user had enabled Radar for Setup Intents.

title: Untitled
text: We have rolled out a change that only enforces the default CVC verification and postal code verification block rules when Radar is enabled for Setup Intents.

title: Untitled
text: In order to provide greater transparency to our users, we have launched terms which apply to your use of the Stripe Radar Service. The terms are intended to better reflect our obligations and expectations with regard to use of Radar. The Radar Terms are effective immediately for US-based Stripe users who sign up to our Stripe Services Agreement on or after May 9, 2022 and for existing US-based Radar for Fraud Team Stripe users via Dashboard notification.

title: FAQ
text: On March 15, 2024, a set of industry guidelines that outline security measures for businesses that conduct card payments in Japan, the "Credit Card Security Guidelines,” was revised (see Credit Card Security Guidelines Version 6.0 ).

title: FAQ
text: The Credit Card Security Guidelines state that merchants who conduct online sales (Stripe users) must enable 3D Secure authentication by the end of March 2025 in order to combat fraud.

title: FAQ
text: 3D Secure authentication (3DS) is a mechanism that provides an additional layer of authentication for credit card payments and protects businesses from liability for fraudulent card payments.

title: FAQ
text: In January 2025, Stripe started to require 3DS on a small percentage of payments, and gradually increased this to 100% of payments on March 31, 2025, excluding payments that are exempt from the 3DS requirement.

title: FAQ
text: Some credit card payments on older APIs that do not support 3DS (Charges API and Orders API) fail from April 2025. By June 30, 2025, all credit card payments on these APIs will fail.

title: FAQ
text: There are cases where you can decide whether or not to apply 3DS. When payments are made without 3DS by using an exemption, liability shift for fraudulent payments doesn’t apply. Please refer to our documentation to see how Stripe implements 3DS exemptions.

title: FAQ
text: We recommend using Stripe’s test card numbers to check that your integration works with 3DS. You can learn more about testing in our documentation .

title: FAQ
text: Neither the Charges API nor the Orders API support 3D Secure 2. As a result, if your account uses these legacy APIs, credit card payments will fail. We strongly recommend that you migrate to the Payment Intents API as soon as possible to avoid failures.

title: FAQ
text: You need to ensure that your integration can handle the requires_action state to prompt your customers to authenticate their payments. You may need to update your integration to handle card authentication .

title: FAQ
text: Also if you finalize payments on the server , you need to take additional steps to show the 3DS authentication flow on the client. Refer to this guide for more details.

title: FAQ
text: You’ll need to either upgrade to version 2019-03-14 or newer of the API, or use the payment_behavior parameter as described in this guide to ensure that the initial payments of your customers’ subscriptions are authenticated.

title: FAQ
text: If you use Stripe through a third-party integration or third-party platform, you’ll need to check directly with them to learn about their readiness.

title: FAQ
text: Be prepared for questions from your customers about 3DS. Also, if necessary, ensure that any necessary support content for your customers describes the 3DS requirement.

title: FAQ
text: Stripe Radar helps prevent fraud by analyzing payment data from over a million companies worldwide and detecting and blocking fraudulent payments. Radar uses machine learning to conduct risk assessments based on hundreds of signals, including card type, country of use, device, and behavior. Stripe offers three default Radar rules that dynamically request 3DS. By setting these rules in the dashboard, additional authentication can be requested from customers when their card issuing company requires 3DS.

title: FAQ
text: With Radar for Fraud Teams, which allows for custom rule settings, businesses can tailor their own unique risk management settings for 3DS. 3DS requests can be made based on risk levels or specific metadata, helping prevent excessive blocking of legitimate payments, reduce the decline rate of payments, and maximize revenue.

title: FAQ
text: Use of Radar may help to mitigate loss of conversion while allowing for risk-based anti-fraud measures. Additionally, Radar can be used to conduct the required risk analysis for Customer-Initiated payments against saved cards.

title: FAQ
text: There is no fine, but a merchant investigation may be issued through Stripe or the acquirer, who can instruct the merchant to enact necessary security measures if the merchant has not taken appropriate steps to prevent fraudulent use and protect credit card numbers. If, regardless of such instructions, a merchant does not adopt the security measures, they may be offboarded as a merchant.

title: FAQ
text: In most cases, there are no additional fees for 3DS. However, if your account has a custom pricing plan, you may incur fees for each 3DS attempt.

title: FAQ
text: If you're using Stripe through a third-party integration or plugin, you may still need to make changes to comply with the new 3DS requirements. The exact steps will depend on your third-party provider's implementation. We recommend reaching out to your third-party or plugin provider as soon as possible to confirm that they're preparing for these regulations and to understand any updates you might need to make on your end.

title: FAQ
text: You can use a test API key along with test cards to create test transactions. By using test cards that require authentication, you can validate the 3DS authentication. Stripe does not offer a special environment for testing the Japan 3DS mandate rules and our support team is unable to verify your integration for you.

title: FAQ
text: For accounts in Japan, you need to comply with the new 3DS requirements for both domestic and international cards. Accounts outside Japan are not subject to this requirement.

title: FAQ
text: Even if there are exceptions for 3DS , it may be desirable to incur a liability shift by manually triggering 3DS due to suspected fraud. You can do this by using Radar rules on the dashboard or using the API.

title: FAQ
text: Both scenarios result in a liability shift . If you want to specify the challenge flow in the Payment Intents API, set ‘ request_three_d_secure ’ to challenge.

title: FAQ
text: If your business involves saving cards in advance, you need to verify that the customer logging in is indeed the account holder. You must implement strict account management and measures against unauthorized logins.

title: FAQ
text: You can implement this using the Setup Intents API , whereby Stripe will automatically trigger 3DS under the following conditions, or utilize the setup mode in Checkout to trigger 3DS by default during card registration.

title: FAQ
text: If 3DS authentication has been completed during card registration, it will be exempt for subsequent transactions. However, for each transaction, you should assess the fraud risk based on transaction amount, goods/services, attributes, and behavioral analysis, and if deemed necessary, you will need to perform 3DS authentication again. In such cases, use SetupIntent once more.

title: FAQ
text: If you use the Subscriptions API and don't create a SetupIntent object manually after card entry, one will be created for you if 3DS is required. You'll need to handle this on your frontend to allow your user to complete 3DS authentication.

title: FAQ
text: For recurring payments, if 3DS authentication has been completed at the time of card registration or the first payment, it can be exempted for subsequent payments, and you will not need to perform 3DS authentication. However, if there are any customer interactions related to contract changes or additional purchases, you will need to perform 3DS authentication again.

title: Untitled
text: If a payment requires 3D Secure authentication but we are unable to initiate it, we will make a final attempt to complete the payment without authentication. The results from this fallback charge updates the PaymentIntent status to one of the following:

title: Untitled
text: Typically, a payment that triggers 3D Secure will result in a PaymentIntent with a status of requires_action . Here is a walkthrough of a typical payment flow that requests 3D Secure:

title: Untitled
text: If steps 4 or 5 is not successful, then the above payment flow would change to look something like this:

title: Untitled
text: The reason we attempt this instead of immediately blocking the payment or returning an error, is that we are choosing to optimize for conversion .

title: Untitled
text: If the fallback charge fails, then the PaymentIntent status updates to requires_payment_method . In the event that this fallback charge is successful, the charge is not covered by liability shift, unless the fallback charge has an attempt_acknowledged status on payment_method_details.card.three_d_secure.result .

title: Untitled
text: For more information on unauthenticated payments and Liability Shift see Using Radar for Fraud Teams to prevent charges without Liability Shift

title: Additional Information
text: Stripe does not send any webhooks between the customer action ( requires_action ) and the last confirmation ( requires_confirmation ).

title: Additional Information
text: You can manually set a redirect to forward the request from your client side to the server side to trigger the second confirmation.

title: Additional Information
text: If you are using the Setup Intents API to set up off-session recurring payments for Strong Customer Authentication (SCA) compliance and the test card ending in 3184 is requiring 3D Secure authentication for every charge, instead use the test card ending in 3155 instead to test one-time payments. The card ending in 3184 is meant for testing authentication on all transactions, regardless of how the card is set up.

title: Additional Information
text: If a subscription payment fails due to authentication issues when using 3D Secure, the payment will not automatically retry based on your retry settings. Unauthorized payments are still considered active, as they are waiting to be authenticated and have not technically failed as payments.

title: Additional Information
text: To notify your customers of authentication issues with their payments, you'll need to enable the Send a Stripe-hosted link for customers to confirm their payments when required toggle in your Billing settings , where you can also configure other Billing options such as your Smart Retry settings.

title: Additional Information
text: If you're implementing a new Billing integration and would like to handle the 3DS recovery flow yourself, follow the guidance in our Billing Implementation for New Integrations guide.

title: Additional Information
text: If you're looking for information on making your existing Billing integration SCA-compliant, visit our SCA migration guide for Billing .

title: Additional information
text: When authenticating a card payment with 3D Secure 2 (3DS2) , Stripe collects certain information about the customer’s device via Stripe.js and the iOS and Android SDKs. This information is shared with the card network and issuing bank — as required by the 3DS2 protocol — to help them recognize repeat payments from the same device and assess the transaction’s overall risk.

title: Additional information
text: While the 3DS2 protocol requests over 150 data elements , Stripe protects user privacy by only collecting a handful of elements: core IDs and environment information that we believe are sufficient for the issuing bank’s risk analysis.

title: Additional information
text: As part of a fingerprinting step introduced in 3DS2, Stripe.js may open a hidden iframe to the issuing bank, allowing the bank to run their own proprietary fingerprinting scripts. (We’re aware this approach to fingerprinting will become ineffective as browsers implement double-keyed storage; we’re working with the W3C and the card networks to develop a privacy-preserving alternative.)

title: Additional information
text: App-specific device ID: identifierForVendor on iOS, ANDROID_ID on Android. (Note: apps installed prior to Android 8.0 will observe a global ANDROID_ID instead of an app-specific value.)

title: Additional information
text: In addition, the 3D Secure 2 specification references a number of data elements which the iOS and Android SDKs do not collect.

title: Additional information
text: To ensure your app complies with App Store and Play Store policies, the iOS and Android SDKs do not collect the Advertising ID.

title: Additional information
text: The iOS and Android SDKs do not collect hardware identifiers (IMEI, MAC address) or user preferences (vibrate mode setting, list of installed apps) except as described above. Access to these categories of information is being phased out by platform providers, and we don’t believe the data significantly improve risk decisioning.

title: Additional information
text: The iOS and Android SDKs encrypt device information using a key held by the card network. Stripe’s servers do not have access to these data.

title: Additional information
text: Note: the iOS and Android SDKs perform basic checks to detect rooted devices, per PCI 3DS requirements. Only a boolean value representing whether the check succeeded or failed is transmitted to the server. Also per PCI 3DS requirements, the components of the Android SDK involved in 3DS2 are obfuscated with ProGuard.

title: Additional information
text: 3D Secure device information is collected after confirming the PaymentIntent or SetupIntent (i.e. when you call confirmCardPayment or equivalent). This typically occurs once the customer clicks the “Pay” button on the payment page.

title: Additional information
text: Collecting device information is a required part of the 3D Secure 2 protocol and is only triggered during the payment process. It is not affected by the advancedFraudSignals parameter.

title: Additional information
text: If you have feedback on the device information collected by Stripe.js and the iOS and Android SDKs, please reach out to Stripe Support .

title: Additional information
text: If you're looking for information on handling 3DS with recurring payments, follow the Stripe Billing guide in our docs .

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Card payments in Malaysia are subject to authentication using 3D Secure , which introduces an extra layer of security for customers making purchases online. To avoid an increase in declines when transacting with Malaysian cardholders, you might need to make integration changes.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Stripe Checkout supports payment authentication out the gate. If you’re using the Charges API, which does not support authentication, you will need to make changes to your integration . The Payment Intents API and Setup Intents API both support authentication, however you need to ensure your integration can handle the `requires_action` state as this will prompt your customers to authenticate their payments. If you’re not sure if your integration can handle authentication or are receiving a large amount of declines due to `authentication_required`, we recommend testing your integration with our 3D Secure authentication test cards .

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: As a payment service provider, Stripe aims to keep bad actors out of the payment ecosystem and deter fraudulent activities that impact both our users and their customers. As online scams/fraudulent activities are reportedly on the riseA in Malaysia, Stripe has taken precautionary steps to enhance the mitigation measures, such as requesting customer authentication when a suspicious payment activity is detected. Stripe’s enhanced efforts to deter fraudulent activities are in line with Malaysia’s regulatory expectations of payment service providers, and aims to mitigate the impact of fraudulent transactions.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: 3D Secure, or 3DS for short, is an authentication protocol used to add an extra layer of security to online transactions. When a transaction is authenticated using 3DS, liability for any fraudulent activity shifts to the issuing bank. This additional security comes with a tradeoff, namely an extra step during the checkout flow.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Yes, the Charges API V1 does not support authentication, so you will need to migrate to the Payment Intents API . It is important to test your integration to ensure it can handle authentication requests. Otherwise you will see an increase in declined payments with error code `authentication_required`.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: The Payment Intents API and Setup Intents API both support authentication, however you need to ensure your integration can handle the ` requires_action` state as this will prompt your customers to authenticate their payments.

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: If you are not sure, we recommend testing your integration with our 3D Secure authentication test cards to get the best understanding of the path forward.

title: Additional Information
text: Invoices will automatically generate PaymentIntents objects and will indicate when a next action is needed. invoice.payment_action_required will generate when a next action is needed such as requiring 3D Secure, and the hosted_invoice_url returned in that event contains a button for the customer to complete the payment.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe Connect is compliant with Payment Services Directive 2 (PSD2). For more details, you can read our guide to Strong Customer Authentication (SCA).

title: Untitled
text: In the United States: Terminal processes co-branded debit transactions in the US through the credit card networks (Visa, MasterCard, Discover etc.). Cards in the United States run across credit rails rather than debit rails, and typically no PIN is required for cardholder verification. In the event a PIN is required (for example, for cards issued internationally ), the Stripe Reader S700 and WisePOS E readers will prompt for a PIN. Stripe Reader M2 will not prompt for a PIN, however this does not impede general acceptance as PINless transactions are allowed to be run on readers without a PINpad. Co-branded debit cards (which support both a local debit network and the Visa, Mastercard or Discover networks) are accepted, and make up the vast majority of debit cards issued in the US. However, debit cards that do not support Visa, Mastercard, or Discover co-branding are not.

title: Untitled
text: In Canada: Terminal processes Interac Debit transactions as PIN debit. Both credit card and Interac debit payments may require customers to enter their PIN on the card reader to complete the transaction.

title: Untitled
text: In Europe and Asia Pacific: Terminal processes co-branded debit transactions through the credit card networks and will prompt for PIN when required. In European markets, there are regulatory requirements around PIN authentication for transactions. Please view PIN and Strong Customer Authentication requirements here .

title: Untitled
text: In Australia: eftpos is the interbank network that handles routing of debit payments in Australia. A majority of consumer debit cards in Australia are branded with an eftpos logo and co-branded with Visa or Mastercard. Terminal processes co-branded debit transactions through both the credit card networks and eftpos, depending on the type of transaction. Terminal also supports mono-branded debit cards. In both cases, the Terminal will prompt for PIN when required.

title: Untitled
text: In New Zealand: eftpos is the interbank network that handles routing of debit payments in New Zealand. Consumer debit cards in New Zealand are branded with an eftpos logo and may also be co-branded with Visa or Mastercard. Stripe can support co-branded eftpos over the co-brand rails.

title: Untitled
text: No – the Stripe Reader M2 is not supported outside of the US as it only supports PINless transactions. PIN support is required for processing transactions in many markets, including the United Kingdom and Ireland.

title: Untitled
text: Terminal’s mobile readers work with iOS, Android and React Native SDKs and use Bluetooth Low Energy to connect to the SDKs on an Android/iOS device, these include: Stripe Reader M2 (US only), and BBPOS WisePad 3 (outside of the US).

title: Untitled
text: Stripe's mobile app is available for accounts that access the Stripe Dashboard, which includes Standard accounts and excludes Custom and Express accounts.

title: Untitled
text: To use the mobile app, you need to enable two-step authentication on your Stripe account. Each time you log in to your account on the mobile app, you’ll be prompted to enter a verification code.

title: Untitled
text: We don't support Google login credentials in the mobile app. To log in, make sure that you have set a password for your Stripe account. This can be done through the Stripe Dashboard on the User page.

title: Untitled
text: If you’re still unable to log in and it’s not related to two-step authentication or the account type or role, check that you have the latest version of the app installed on your device.

title: Untitled
text: It’s likely that you don’t have the right permissions to do so. You’ll need to get in touch with the administrator of your account to update your role. You should also ensure that you have the latest version of the app installed on your device.

title: Untitled
text: If you cannot create a payout and the message is: "Please verify your phone number to create payments via the Dashboard." You can complete the phone number verification here and payouts will be enabled afterwords.

title: Untitled
text: Exporting data from your Payments page of the Dashboard allows you to access historical transaction data. You can customize the export by selecting your preferred time zone, date range, and columns, as well as various payment types, such as successful, refunded, or uncaptured payments, and associated fees. Fees displayed in the export include both Stripe processing fees and any application fees charged by connected platforms.

title: Untitled
text: From the Payments page in the Dashboard, click Export . From there, you can select your preferred time zone, date range, and desired columns. This will download a CSV file to your device covering all of your payments.

title: Untitled
text: Fees included in this export sum both standard Stripe processing fees and application fees that can be charged by platforms you are connected to. Application fees are also viewable in the Transactions > Collected fees section of the Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: To do this, on the Refunds page, click Export. From there, you can select your preferred time zone, date range, and desired columns. This will download a CSV report to your device covering all of your Refunds.

title: Untitled
text: You can use the Balance history to export individual activity in your account, like payments, refunds and disputes. Every payment-related transaction is listed here, making accounting over specific periods of time much easier.

title: Untitled
text: For context, the Payments export is intended for deeply granular charge detail that can be helpful for customer service issues.

title: Untitled
text: The payments export also includes failed transactions and handles refunds differently than our accounting tools, which means it won't line up with the Monthly Report.

title: Untitled
text: You can filter your reports further by date, amount, payment success status, or payment method by clicking 'Filter' on the upper left corner of the page.

title: Untitled
text: When exporting reports, you can also have the option of having multiple metadata fields included in your reports, including card brand, product description, and country of customer, among other fields. To do this,

title: Untitled
text: If you have any custom metadata columns added to your payments, these columns will be included in the exports by default. Though metadata is not explicitly listed on the available columns, exporting the report will automatically include the metadata.

title: Untitled
text: If you have examined the available columns (make sure to select ‘All’ columns to review all the available data) and can’t find what you’re looking for there are two options.

title: Untitled
text: First option: If the data does not currently exist in Stripe, you could consider adding this information as Metadata to customers, payments or other data within Stripe. You can then export this metadata alongside the customers, charges, or other data it relates to.

title: Untitled
text: Second option: If the information already exists within Stripe, or you’re simply looking for more advanced options for analyzing all available information, you can consider using Stripe Sigma to write custom SQL queries across your data.

title: Untitled
text: Our Balance Reports and Payout Reconciliation Report pages can be exported as PDF. The resulting PDF will include key information such as:

title: Untitled
text: On the main home page of the Stripe Dashboard, you will see a number of charts that provide account information at a glance. You can customize this page to help you keep on top of your business' financial information and quickly carry out your most common workflows.

title: Untitled
text: To browse all the charts and data available, click Edit overview → Add to add or remove widgets. When you’re done, click Apply to see the changes reflected on your homepage.

title: Untitled
text: If you get paid out in multiple currencies, Stripe home charts show payment and payout information with the Foreign Exchange Rate conversion applied. This conversion is an estimate as the exchange rate changes over time: Stripe uses sample exchange rates over the time period selected, but this will not match exactly with settled amounts for merchants that settle in multiple currencies.

title: Untitled
text: Sometimes Stripe payouts fail to complete and you will receive a notification asking you to update your bank account details. That usually happens because there was an issue with the bank account information provided. Below the most common causes for payout failures in Stripe Brazil accounts and how to resolve them:

title: Untitled
text: If your Stripe account is Pessoa Física, the bank account added must be associated with the same CPF entered in your Stripe account. If your Stripe account is Pessoa Jurídica (or associated with a CNPJ), the bank account must be associated with the same CNPJ. A mismatch in this information can cause payouts to fail.

title: Untitled
text: The bank details must also be in the correct format: enter your bank account number with numbers only (no hyphens) including the digit.

title: Untitled
text: For Caixa Econômica Federal account holders, the checking account should have 12 digits; it must include the operation code (3 digits): 001,002,003, and the checking account (9 digits including zeros): Ex: 001 000456789.

title: Untitled
text: Your account must be a checking account – we do not work with transfers to savings and salary accounts. This is because the salary account does not allow receiving credits (deposits and transfers) from third parties, only from the employer. The savings account only accepts transfers from the same ownership. If your bank account is a university account, check with your bank whether you can receive TED/DOC on this account. The university account also has restrictions, but it depends on each bank and the package of services contracted.

title: Untitled
text: You will need a Brazilian-based bank account that's BRL denominated to receive your Stripe payouts. Your bank also needs to be a domiciled institution as per Central Bank regulation. Full list of Domiciled Institutions can be found in here (under Participantes > Participantes Homologados).

title: Untitled
text: Always review your bank account details before submitting the form to prevent delays to receive your payout. If you have followed the requirements above and you are still having issues to receive your payouts, please visit this article for guidance.

title: Untitled
text: Prior to January 1, 2023, our business structure was not subject to Italy’s e-invoicing requirements—which is why you have not received an e-invoice from us before.

title: Untitled
text: From January 1, 2023 through June 30, 2025, due to a change in our business structure, and a local presence in Italy, made us subject to Italy’s e-invoicing requirements. To comply with these requirements, we issued e-invoices via Sistema di Interscambio (SDI) to all Italian businesses that use Stripe from January 1, 2023 through June 30, 2025.

title: Untitled
text: During this time, as a Connect platform based in Italy, Stripe provided you with payment processing services subject to the fees displayed on the Stripe Pricing Page. Because you selected a direct charge configuration for your connected accounts, we debited our Stripe fees from your connected account(s). To comply with Italy’s VAT requirements, however, we are required to collect VAT from you and issue an invoice for the services provided to your platform. We recommend that you consult with your tax adviser on your obligations with respect to your connected accounts.

title: Untitled
text: For services provided after July 1, 2025, Stripe will provide services through Ireland. If you think you may need to self-account (“reverse charge”) for local VAT in your jurisdiction on the services received from Stripe (product and service fees), we recommend contacting a tax advisor or accountant for support. Stripe will deliver a tax invoice to your Dashboard that includes monthly activity on your Stripe account. This is not an e-invoice.

title: Untitled
text: No. As you have contracted with Stripe for payment processing services, the invoice we have issued to you represents the Stripe fees that we have debited from your connected accounts. We do not debit those same fees directly from your account. If you would like to reimburse your connected accounts for Stripe fees, you can use the Send funds button in the Balance section.

title: Untitled
text: For connected account direct charge transactions, we debit Stripe fees from your connected account(s) on your behalf. For these transactions that occur between January 1, 2019 through June 30, 2026, the 22% Italian VAT due on this fee is debited from your account.

title: Untitled
text: Please refer to the connected account details page Payments section, where you can click on individual transactions for more details.

title: Untitled
text: Once in the Payments section, you can click on the transaction for more details. You can see a breakdown of the Stripe fees debited from your connected account on your behalf by hovering your mouse cursor over the gray “info” icon next to the Fee amount.

title: Untitled
text: As part of Faster Payment System guidelines in the UK, Stripe is required to block payout statement descriptors containing profanities. If profanities remain in your statement descriptor after October 1, 2024 Stripe may pause payouts on your account.

title: Untitled
text: If you have a custom payout statement descriptor configured on your merchant account, contact Stripe support to update your payout statement descriptor

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Stripe Startups is a by-application program to help venture-backed startups that are just getting started. It gives founders of early-stage, venture-backed startups access to financial benefits in the form of waived processing fees or fee credits (depending on the country), a focused community of other builders and Stripe leaders, and expert resources.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Stripe Startups is designed for early-stage, venture-backed companies. In order to qualify, your application must include proof of institutional funding. You may provide any of the following to verify funding: link to PitchBook (or similar) naming your investors, links to articles featuring funding announcements (e.g., TechCrunch articles, VC websites), other documentation verifying your company’s funding status.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: If you meet the qualifying criteria for Stripe Startups but have received a prior fee offer, your application to Stripe Startups may be approved even though you may no longer be eligible for further offers.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Depending on what country you are in, you may either be eligible for product fee credits or for waived processing fees . Fee credits are replacing waived processing fees over time. Find your region below to see which offer is available to you.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: “Waived processing fees” mean that Stripe won’t charge you payment processing fees, up to a threshold approved for your account.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: These apply only to payment processing fees for cards and local payment methods , including buy now, pay later and ACH.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Offer amounts vary by offer type (i.e., in the form of fee credits or in the form of waived processing fees on a certain payment volume) and, if applicable, by your referral source. Stripe has standing partnerships with some investors to whom we offer elevated benefits. Venture capital firms and startup accelerators can apply for Stripe benefits for their portfolio companies here .

title: Program eligibility and application
text: The offer expires 12 months from when you activate your offer or until you reach your offer limit—whichever comes first.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Yes. You have 12 months to activate your offer. The 12-month period to use your offer starts only after you activate it. Activate it when you’re ready to process payments.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Log in as an admin or owner. Look for the banner or setup guide task in your Dashboard to accept the offer.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: If you don’t see your offer, make sure that your account is active and that there are no outstanding verification banners. You can also check the Fee Credits section under Reports, or Fee Discounts section under Reports —though, this section will only appear if you have completed your Business Profile.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Check your remaining balance in the Fee Credits section under Reports in your Dashboard. Fee Credits show how much of your offer you’ve used so far.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Check your remaining balance in the Fee Discounts section under Balances in your Dashboard. Fee Discounts show how much of your offer you’ve used so far.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Offers apply to individual accounts, not all accounts tied to one email. Make sure you’re logged in to the correct account when applying.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: A startup can only redeem one offer in its lifetime, even if you have multiple Stripe accounts (e.g., one in Mexico and one in the US). The offer applies to one account, so you’ll have to decide which one to use it on. Though, if you manage multiple eligible startups, each one that is affiliated with a Stripe referral partner can receive its own offer, even if you are the founder of or are associated with all of them.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: No, the offer only starts after offer activation. Be sure to activate it only when you’re ready to process payments.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: First, only fee credit offers are eligible to use on Connect (waived processing fee offers may not be used on Stripe product fees).

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Second, it depends on how you’re using Stripe Connect. You can select different Connect configurations that allow you to identify who is responsible for collecting payment fees, who is responsible for negative balances, and what kind of dashboard experience you want for your connected accounts. The application of this offer differs based on who pays Stripe fees ( controller.fees.payer ) in your Connect integration.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Yes. The offer will convert to the currency of your default bank account, so you can still use it even if your customers pay in a different currency. That said, if you have more than one bank account with different settlement currencies (e.g., one for EUR, another for USD), the offer will only apply to payouts sent to the account in your default currency (e.g., EUR if that was the default). For details on supported currencies, head here .

title: Program eligibility and application
text: You’ll still see a fee listed on each charge, but they’ll be combined and credited back to you as an adjustment. That happens when we calculate the total for each payout.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: These two programs can be stacked. That is, you may be enrolled in both and obtain offers through each program. You can learn more about the Atlas program here .

title: Program eligibility and application
text: The offer processes when payouts are calculated, not immediately after transactions. You’ll still see fees listed on each charge, but they’ll be combined and credited back to your account as an adjustment in your payout total.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Contact them directly and ask for the link. Venture capital firms and startup accelerators can apply for Stripe benefits for their portfolio companies at https://stripe.com/startups/partners .

title: Program eligibility and application
text: If your business processes over $100,000 in monthly payments for 3 consecutive months, you can request a pricing review. Otherwise, standard fees will apply.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Stripe evaluates your payment volume, card mix, and other factors to determine if you qualify for custom pricing. Note that not all Stripe users who receive a pricing review qualify for custom pricing.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: No, the offer starts once you activate it and can’t be paused. If you’re not ready to start processing payments, it’s a good idea to wait before activating it.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: We don’t send reminders for expiring offers right now, but you can track your remaining balance in the Fee Credits section of your Dashboard.

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Unfortunately, we can only extend one offer per startup. If your case is unique, feel free to contact us .

title: Program eligibility and application
text: Stripe’s developer documentation and the Stripe Developers channel on Discord are great resources, in addition to Stripe support , where you can search our support site or connect with our support team.

title: Untitled
text: All of the card readers offered through Stripe Terminal support contactless EMV (​​Europay, MasterCard and Visa), including payment methods like Apple Pay, Google Pay, and Samsung Pay.

title: FAQs
text: Starting April 1, 2024, we will decrease our domestic card processing fees for Australian businesses on standard pricing from 1.75% + A$0.30 to 1.70% + A$0.30 for online ( Card Not Present ) payments, and from 1.75% + A$0.10 to 1.70% + A$0.10 for Stripe Terminal ( Card Present) payments.

title: FAQs
text: This change is enabled by least-cost routing . In most cases, when your customers pay with debit cards issued in Australia, two card networks are presented for each transaction. Stripe generally routes to the network with lower average cost when feasible, and passes those savings on to you. Learn mo re .

title: FAQs
text: This change applies to successful domestic credit or debit card transactions processed through Stripe for all card networks including Visa, Mastercard, American Express, eftpos, JCB, and UnionPay. There is no change to processing fees for international cards.

title: FAQs
text: These changes apply to all businesses on Stripe’s standard pricing plan . If you’re on a custom pricing plan, there will be no changes to your current pricing.

title: FAQs
text: If you use Connect with Standard accounts, these changes will apply to the Stripe fees for your connected accounts. Stripe will automatically notify your connected accounts about the changes. There’s no action needed from you, but you are welcome to share additional communication with them about the change.

title: FAQs
text: If you use Connect with Custom accounts, these changes will apply to your Stripe fees starting April 1, 2024. You are responsible for any updates to your own pricing in line with these changes, and for communicating with your users.

title: FAQs
text: The best way to calculate the impact these changes might have to your business is to use the Stripe Dashboard.

title: FAQs
text: This support page provides you with more details on the notice we sent you describing changes to certain fees. That notice is a legal notice sent to Stripe users, even those who have unsubscribed from optional marketing notices. You cannot unsubscribe from legal notices, but if you’d prefer not to receive any further legal notices from Stripe, you can close your account by following these steps .

title: FAQs
text: Your continued use of Stripe's services after April 1, 2024 is subject to these fee changes. Any termination rights you have under your agreement with us are unaffected by this change.

title: FAQs
text: There’s no action necessary for you at this time and these changes will automatically apply to your business and/or your connected accounts on April 1, 2024.

title: What’s changing?
text: Stripe Issuing is updating its shipping options, card printing fees, and disputes process. These new changes will go into effect on September 15, 2023.

title: What’s changing?
text: If you have questions about the pricing changes, or you aren’t sure if they apply to you, reach out to your account representative or our support team .

title: What’s changing?
text: We try to offer you printing prices at cost. As the cost of printing a physical card has gone up, we’ve needed to increase our prices to more accurately reflect the underlying expense to Stripe

title: What’s changing?
text: Standard cards are our default black or white card designs that feature your logo. For an additional cost, you can design your own card artwork. These are called custom cards .

title: What’s changing?
text: Custom cards continue to be priced based on your design and order volume. As the cost of manufacturing specific designs changes, your pricing may also change. You can learn more about custom card pricing here .

title: What’s changing?
text: Different features in a card design may impact its printing cost. Reach out to your Stripe sales contact, and we can help you with design modifications to reduce cost. You can learn more about custom card pricing here .

title: What’s changing?
text: We’re introducing new shipping options. Domestic and international shipping will have separate pricing, and some domestic shipping prices will increase based on carrier rates. Signatures will be optional for most shipping options to help you lower costs. Other changes apply, see our full list of shipping costs here .

title: What’s changing?
text: Signatures add an additional cost to shipping that isn’t always necessary. We stopped requiring signatures by default so you could better control your shipping costs.

title: What’s changing?
text: Carrier rates regularly increase their rates. As their prices go up, Stripe adjusts our pricing to more accurately reflect their rates.

title: What’s changing?
text: To lower your shipping costs, you can choose a slower shipping option, ship your card in bulk or opt to not require signatures.

title: What’s changing?
text: Disputes offer cardholders the right to be reimbursed by the associated merchant for prior transactions (usually due to fraud, but also for other disagreements). When a dispute occurs, an investigation takes place to determine if the cardholder should be reimbursed. Card networks charge Stripe fees for every submitted dispute, regardless of the outcome, and Stripe incurs costs to investigate them on our user’s behalf.

title: What’s changing?
text: We’re updating our policy to no longer return the $15 dispute fee for successfully contested disputes. The dispute fee itself is not changing.

title: What’s changing?
text: Stripe is charged a dispute fee regardless of the outcome of a dispute. We’ve updated our policy to reflect these costs.

title: What’s changing?
text: Stripe Issuing provides new fraud prevention tooling to avoid unauthorized transactions before they are authorized and disputed. You should also guide your cardholders to work with merchants directly to resolve non-fraud disputes outside of the card network processes.

title: What’s changing?
text: This support page provides you with more details on the notice we sent you describing changes to certain fees. That notice is a legal notice sent to Stripe users, even those who have unsubscribed from optional marketing notices. You cannot unsubscribe from legal notices, but if you’d prefer not to receive any further legal notices from Stripe, you can close your account by following these steps .

title: What’s changing?
text: Your continued use of Stripe's services after September 15, 2023 is subject to these fee and shipping changes. Any termination rights you have under your agreement with us are unaffected by this change.

title: What’s changing?
text: There’s no action necessary for you.These changes will automatically apply to existing platforms and their connected accounts from September 15, 2023.

title: Untitled
text: You can connect the Terminal smart reader (WisePOS E, S700) to your point of sale application by establishing a local area network (LAN) connection between the devices. We recommend an Ethernet connection to connect your reader. Note that the Verifone P400 reader also requires a connection to Stripe over the internet.

title: Untitled
text: Depending on your machine, you may be able to bridge an internet connection via Ethernet from your computer to your reader. You should refer to instructions for your computer’s operating system on bridged internet connections or internet sharing to set this up.

title: Untitled
text: The BBPOS WisePOS E is a smart reader with a 5” touchscreen display ideal for hybrid countertop and handheld use.

title: Untitled
text: If you have an existing Stripe Terminal integration using the Verifone P400, no additional work is required to support the BBPOS WisePOS E. If you do not have an existing Stripe Terminal integration with the Verifone P400, you will need to start a new integration with server-driven or the JavaScript, Android or iOS SDK.

title: Untitled
text: The BBPOS WisePOS E brings a number of new capabilities, including a 5” touchscreen, and battery and plug-in operation, enabling it to be used both on your countertop and on-the-go. In addition, the BBPOS WisePOS E runs on a modern Android-based operating system, allowing it to be updated with new features for fleet management, additional use cases, and more.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe stopped selling the Verifone P400 reader on September 13, 2021. New features and functionality, such as on-reader tipping and additional country support, are available on the WisePOS E and Stripe Reader S700.

title: Untitled
text: After October 1, 2024 , Stripe will move the Verifone P400 reader to end of life status; this means that the reader will no longer be able to process transactions or receive customer support or critical software updates after this date.

title: Untitled
text: As the reader will be moved to end of life status, we recommend that you transition to the BBPOS WisePOS E or Stripe Reader S700. No additional integration work is required to change to these readers.

title: Untitled
text: The WisePOS E connects to your web-based or mobile point of sale application via WiFI or Ethernet. Ethernet connectivity requires the use of an optional dock, which provides hardwired ethernet connectivity while also keeping your smart reader fully charged using the included charging cable.

title: Untitled
text: The serial number is listed in small letters on the back of the reader in the second line of text after 'SN'. You can also find the reader serial number after connecting to the reader using the iOS & Android example app. The serial number begins with the prefix ' STRM2 '.

title: Untitled
text: The serial number is printed on the back of the reader. It begins with ' WPC ' and is printed on the second line of text beginning with 'S/N'. Not to be confused with 'HW No.' on the third line.

title: Untitled
text: The serial number is listed on the back of the reader above the magnetic pins where it says 'SN'. It begins with ' STR7 ' followed by letters and digits. If you have a DevKit version of the S700, the serial number begins with ' SDR7 '. You can also find the reader serial number in the dashboard when viewing readers for a specific location or the list of ungrouped readers.

title: Untitled
text: The serial number is listed on a sticker on the back of the reader. It begins with ' WSC ' followed by 12 digits and is printed on the second line of text beginning with 'S/N'. Not to be confused with 'HW No.' on the third line. You can also find the reader serial number in the dashboard when viewing readers for a specific location or the list of ungrouped readers.

title: Untitled
text: The serial number is listed on the back of the reader and is listed on the reader box label under 'S/N'. Verifone P400 serial numbers are in the format ' 123-456-789 ' You can also find the reader serial number in the dashboard when viewing readers for a specific location or the list of ungrouped readers.

title: Untitled
text: The serial number is listed in small letters on the back of the reader under 'serial'. You can also find the reader serial number after connecting to the reader using the iOS & Android example app. The serial number begins with the prefix ' CHB20 '.

title: Quick Steps
text: If you are have issues with WiFi, you can also connect with Ethernet via the use of an optional dock . This provides wired Ethernet connectivity and keeps your smart reader fully charged using the included charging cable. You can purchase the dock separately through the Stripe Dashboard.

title: FAQs
text: Starting June 1, 2024, UK businesses will be charged a 1.5% international transaction fee when customers pay with a European bank-based payment method (SEPA Direct Debit, Bancontact, EPS, Giropay, iDEAL, Multibanco, Przelewy24, and Sofort).

title: FAQs
text: Since Brexit, Stripe incurs costs for international transactions between the UK and the rest of Europe. To cover these costs, starting June 1, 2024, we will start charging a 1.5% fee for payments made to UK businesses using European bank-based payment methods. This fee is in line with our fees for international transactions in other countries.

title: FAQs
text: This fee is applied when payments are made to UK businesses using a European bank-based payment method (SEPA Direct Debit, Bancontact, EPS, Giropay, iDEAL, Multibanco, Przelewy24, and Sofort). All other payment methods are excluded.

title: FAQs
text: These changes apply to all users on Stripe’s standard pricing for European bank-based payment methods. If you’re on a custom pricing plan for any of these payment methods there will be no changes to your current pricing.

title: FAQs
text: Our research shows that offering relevant local payment methods through our pre-built Payment Element or Checkout increases revenue by 5.4% on average for European businesses, so we recommend keeping bank-based payment methods turned on. You can modify your payment methods at any time in the Dashboard.
