title: Untitled
text: While on a desktop or laptop computer, navigate to the “Reports” section of the Stripe Dashboard and ensure “Balance” is selected directly underneath the Search bar. On this page, you’re able to see what fees Stripe has previously returned to you for all refunded charges. This amount is displayed as “Fees returned” within the “Balance change from activity” module. Please note that this amount reflects returned fees during the time period selected near the top of the page.

title: Untitled
text: Within the “Reports” section of the Dashboard, please click “Download” located at the top-right hand of the “Balance change from activity” module. Export your balance activity to a .CSV file, and ensure “Card country” is selected as a column. Any non-domestic cards processed for your business will be assessed an international card fee (included with standard processing fees within the “Fee” column).

title: Frequently Asked Questions
text: Treasury users looking for further assistance should complete the bottom section of this Support Form ; it has been auto-populated with a subject line and topic that will route directly to our Treasury support team.

title: Untitled
text: There are some limitations to keep in mind as you evaluate whether a Stripe Treasury integration is a good fit for your business:

title: Untitled
text: Currently only one Financial Account can ever be created for a Connected Account. This is true even if a prior Financial Account has been closed — it is not possible to create another Financial Account in its place. Instead, a new Connected Account must be created if you intend to open a new Financial Account for a user.

title: Untitled
text: We do not currently provide statements for Treasury Financial Accounts, but you are welcome to create customized Financial Account statements on your end and issue those on a regular cadence for your users. If you do choose to create customized statements there are a number of compliance requirements you’ll have to adhere to which you can read more about in our Treasury product documentation.

title: Additional Information
text: You can pay your Corporate Card bill at any time for an amount up to your current balance by selecting the Pay Now option from your Dashboard .

title: Additional Information
text: If the Pay Now option is greyed out and unavailable for use, this is because you do not currently have a balance to be paid off. Transactions cannot be paid off while they are still pending, so the Pay Now button will only be available once transactions are confirmed and posted to your current statement balance.

title: Order your Card
text: Although your virtual card is available to use immediately, you must activate your physical card before it can be used.

title: Additional Information
text: When you make a purchase, a transaction is first authorized for the charge amount. This authorization step confirms to the merchant that you have the funds available to make the purchase. Authorized transactions will appear as “ pending ” in your Dashboard.

title: Additional Information
text: Once a charge is authorized, merchants have up to seven days to capture the funds in order to complete the transaction. If an authorization is captured, the transaction completes, and the “pending” status will be removed and replaced by a “ required ” status if a receipt upload is needed for the transaction, or nothing if no receipt is required.

title: Additional Information
text: If an authorization is not captured, the authorized funds will be released and the transaction will show as “ canceled ”. This can happen manually through merchant action (i.e. if you request a refund from the merchant immediately after making a purchase and the merchant releases the authorization), or automatically if the transaction is not captured within the seven days time.

title: Untitled
text: When banks tell Stripe about an updated card, Stripe replaces the old details such as the old expiration date or card number with the new details. When that happens, Stripe creates an event in your account:

title: Untitled
text: To only filter events where card updater occurred, you can use the List Events API endpoint and only filter on the relevant event type above. You can then ignore events where request[id] is not null , and this would give a view of all instances where a card was updated automatically.

title: Determine the issue
text: Webhooks deliver Events to your Webhook Endpoint using HTTP requests. If Events aren't being delivered to your Webhook Endpoint as expected, this article will help you determine the cause of the issue and fix the problem.

title: Determine the issue
text: Look at the HTTP status code and go to the matching article below for next steps. The information in the Response may also be helpful.

title: Untitled
text: "Timed out" indicates Stripe was able to establish a connection to your server, but it took too long for your server to provide a response. Stripe expects your server to promptly respond with an HTTP status code in the 200–299 range to indicate the Event was successfully received.

title: Untitled
text: Audit your webhook processing code and make sure you return a 2xx status code quickly : If you need to perform long-running tasks after receiving an Event from Stripe you should acknowledge receipt of the Event immediately, then perform the long-running tasks afterward (many people add received Events to an internal queue for serial asynchronous processing)

title: Untitled
text: Make sure your server is operating normally: Check for abnormally high CPU or memory utilization, full storage or disk space issues, and errors or warnings in server logs

title: Untitled
text: This error means we were unable to establish a connection to your server. Confirm the following for your Webhook Endpoint's URL:

title: Untitled
text: The hostname can be resolved to the expected IP address using a DNS tool like nslookup , dig , or an online DNS tool

title: Untitled
text: If the URL is correct, connections from Stripe might be blocked by something like a firewall or network configuration. Confirm the IP addresses Stripe uses for webhooks can access your Webhook Endpoint's URL (you may need to work with your hosting provider to confirm this).

title: Untitled
text: 1. In Stripe’s authentication flow , you’ll be able to see what data the business is requesting to access, and you’ll be able to choose which account(s) you want to share with the business and Stripe. You can also choose not to link your account.

title: Untitled
text: 3. Stripe provides the business with the data they’ve requested and you’ve agreed to share. You may share the account data that Stripe receives from your financial institution, typically including:

title: Untitled
text: You can choose whether or not to link a financial account to your merchant and Stripe, and which financial account(s) you’d like to link. If you choose to link an account, Stripe can access any of the information that your financial institution makes available. However, we will limit your merchant’s access to only the information they request. We will disclose what types of information your merchant has requested in the authentication flow, and you will have to provide consent before we share this information with your merchant.

title: Untitled
text: Merchants specify and request the financial information types they need in order to provide you with an enhanced product experience, and they will disclose why they need these information types. You may then opt to link your account(s) to share the requested information, or you may opt out of information sharing altogether. You can also choose to revoke previously granted access and unlink from the merchant.

title: Untitled
text: Linking your financial account through Stripe’s authentication flow allows your financial institution to share information with Stripe and in turn for Stripe to share permissioned information with your merchant. Merchants must clearly disclose the purpose for collecting your financial account information.

title: Untitled
text: We only give your merchant access to the financial information types they’ve specifically requested and only if you have consented to share that financial information with them through the authentication flow. If your merchant would like to access additional types of information from your account in the future, they will need to obtain your permission. You can also choose to revoke previously granted access and unlink from the merchant.

title: Untitled
text: If you are concerned that your merchant’s use of your information is for a purpose that you did not permit, please file a complaint directly with Stripe so that we can investigate. When filing a complaint, please select “Financial Connections” from the drop-down on the form.

title: Untitled
text: We maintain organizational, technical, and administrative measures designed to protect financial account information against unauthorized access, destruction, loss, alteration, or misuse. In particular, all data associated with financial accounts is encrypted in transit and at rest. Because of the sensitive nature of this information, it is also protected by additional access controls, along with ongoing monitoring to prevent data misuse. Learn more about the safeguards we've put in place to protect data transfers and control access.

title: Untitled
text: Our service providers also protect your users’ information and are required to protect the security and confidentiality of personal data they process for Stripe. Learn more about security at Finicity and MX .

title: Untitled
text: While linking a financial account or looking at your banking portal, you may see that your financial institution is sharing more information with Stripe and our service providers than was requested by your merchant. It is common for financial institutions to grant access to all of the data from the accounts you choose to link, which is why Stripe receives more information than your merchant requested. However, we protect your information by only passing along to your merchant the specific information types they have requested and you have consented to share with them. We also take precautions to secure the information shared with Stripe and our service providers. Learn more about the safeguards we've put in place to protect data transfers and control data access.

The customer’s default currency will be changed when the customer does not have any active subscriptions and you start a new subscription, quote, or subscription schedule for the customer in a new currency.

title: Untitled
text: In February 2020, Google released Chrome 80 and began rolling out new cookie behavior. Details of this change and Google’s rollout plans are available at https://www.chromium.org/updates/same-site .

title: Untitled
text: This change requires cross-site cookies to explicitly declare themselves with the SameSite attribute. Cookies that do not do this will result in a Chrome warning in the developer console and being ignored (not sent with any applicable requests).

title: Untitled
text: All Stripe products (i.e. Elements, Checkout, etc.) that use cookies accessible across sites have been updated and will function the same as before the Chrome 80 release.

title: Untitled
text: However, there may still be some stripe.com cookies set by the Stripe Dashboard, Support Site, or home page that will trigger the Chrome warning on other sites that include the Stripe.js library. We will continue to work at reducing/eliminating these, but these remaining instances do not impact any functionality of Stripe products and only result in a benign warning in the developer console.

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: This note is provided for general information purposes and should not be construed as legal advice. If you have further questions which are specific to your business, we recommend that you speak to a legal advisor.

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: In Croatia, payments processed via cash and cards are subject to the fiscalization law. This also applies to payments made to Croatian businesses via Stripe, originating either from local or international cardholders.

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: Under the fiscalization law, each invoice or receipt issued by a Croatian business must contain a QR code linking to the Croatian tax authority’s website, as well as a unique identifier of the invoice (JIR), and the security code of the issuer (ZKI number) liable for fiscalization. In cases where the invoice is not paid in cash, these elements are not required.

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: The only payment method not currently defined as cash is a direct bank transfer from one bank account to another.

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: ZKI (zaštitni kod izdavatelja) is the security code of the issuer. To sign up for your issuer’s ZKI, you’ll need to fill in the relevant forms and process them with the tax office directly. You can read more information about this process at https://www.fina.hr/fiskalizacija#kako-do-certifikata .

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: Once this is done you’ll be sent a certificate with your company details. This certificate can then be uploaded to your accounting software for processing Invoice Fiscalization.

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: JIR (jedinstveni identifikator računa) is the unique identifier of the invoice. To get the unique JIR number issued for an invoice, you’ll need to report the invoice to the Croatian Tax Authority (Porezna uprava).

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: The business sends an electronically signed XML data message about the transaction to The Croatian Tax Authority (Porezna uprava). This XML data message must include their issuer’s security number (ZKI – zaštitni kod izdavatelja)

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: Croatian Tax Authority (Porezna uprava) checks the XML message, adds a unique invoice identity code (JIR – jedinstveni identifikator računa), and sends back confirmation to the business.

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: The business can then issue a receipt (including the JIR number, ZKI number, and the QR code) and provide it to the customer.

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: Registration of the sale can be verified through the web application of the Tax Authority by entering JIR or by scanning the QR code. The customer can verify the authenticity of the received invoice. Customers can check the invoices at: www.provjeri-racun.hr

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: Stripe does not provide a solution to fiscalize invoices or receipts yet, but we’ve gathered a few third-party solutions* you can use based on recommendations from other Stripe users in Croatia:

title: What is the fiscalization law in Croatia and how does it affect my business?
text: *Please note that while Stripe has gathered positive feedback from its users on these service providers, we have not conducted our own due diligence. Companies’ integration and legal requirements are unique, and they should conduct an analysis of these service providers in consultation with their own technical and legal teams.

title: Claiming Unclaimed Funds For An Inactive Account
text: Note: This article pertains to Standard merchants who have been notified by Stripe that they have unclaimed funds that are subject to escheatment.

title: Claiming Unclaimed Funds For An Inactive Account
text: If you received a letter from Stripe indicating that you have an inactive account with unclaimed funds and you have determined that the balance is owed to you, you will need to work with Stripe to claim your inactive account balance. You can do this by logging into your Stripe Dashboard and requesting an instant payout for the Stripe balance amount included in the letter you received.

title: Claiming Unclaimed Funds For An Inactive Account
text: You may need to verify your Stripe account or update your bank account information. Read more if you're having trouble signing into your Stripe account .

title: Claiming Unclaimed Funds For An Inactive Account
text: If you received a mailed letter from Stripe notifying you that you have an inactive account with unclaimed funds but did not respond by the deadline listed in the letter, Stripe has sent (or escheated) the unclaimed funds to the appropriate US state with your last known address and you can no longer claim your unclaimed funds from Stripe. What you can do instead is go to your state’s unclaimed property website and claim the funds from that US state directly. The National Association of Unclaimed Property Administrators (NAUPA) has an interactive map that can direct you to the official government unclaimed property program for your state. There is no deadline for you to recover unclaimed funds from a US state.

title: Claiming Unclaimed Funds For An Inactive Account
text: No, Stripe is unable to assist in returning the unclaimed funds to you once Stripe sends them to the applicable state agency. Read more on how to contact your applicable state agency directly.

title: Untitled
text: For billing schemes that require charging for the service after it has been delivered, Stripe recommends collecting payment details up front so that you can charge your customer at the right time. However, when using a payment method such as 3D Secure and other payment methods that require a customer action, you will need to bring your user back to their browser or app (on-session) to collect payment.

title: Untitled
text: To handle this flow, you will need to collect payment details at the point of initiating the subscription. When you are ready to charge the customer for the first time, the customer will need to complete payment authentication, such as going through 3D Secure v2 . As your user will not be on-session at this time, you will need to ensure that you can return them to your site or app before you can collect funds.

title: Untitled
text: Use Stripe’s optimized and user-tested confirmation emails. Enable these features by checking the box in the Billing settings section of the Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: There are potential solutions that would allow you to collect authentication at the moment of initiating the subscription, even though you are not actually charging the customer. Rules around this solution are actively being developed by card networks. Stripe is also actively developing solutions in this area and will have an updated API by July 2019. We expect any change in this area to be purely additive, and compatible with what we recommend today.

title: Untitled
text: In Sweden, as of July 2020, if a merchant’s online checkout offers both credit and debit payment methods (such as credit cards and debit cards), legislation requires that the debit payment method must be presented before the credit payment method. Furthermore, if both a debit and credit payment method are available, the credit payment method may not be pre-selected.

title: Untitled
text: Merchants should take note that certain types of payment surcharging are banned from January 13, 2018 under the new payment rules in Europe (“PSD2”).

title: Untitled
text: While this is mostly relevant to merchants accepting payments from consumers (“B2C”), some aspects of the PSD2 surcharge ban also apply to certain business-to-business (“B2B”) payments.

title: Untitled
text: The surcharge ban under PSD2 aims to protect consumers across Europe by prohibiting merchants from charging consumers additional fees for making payments by certain payment methods. For example, merchants, including ticketing, travel and food delivery websites, are no longer allowed to charge consumers additional fees for paying by debit or credit card.

title: Untitled
text: the consumer’s bank or card issuer and the payment provider of the merchant (i.e., Stripe) are both located in the EEA; and

title: Untitled
text: the consumer makes a payment using a debit or credit card, or an EUR payment using direct debit or credit transfer (i.e., a SEPA payment).

title: Untitled
text: Even if the surcharge ban does not apply, the amount of any surcharge imposed cannot exceed the cost incurred by the merchant in accepting the particular payment method.

title: Untitled
text: The scope of the surcharge ban may vary from one country to another – for example, in the UK, HM Treasury has extended the ban to include B2C payments made by payment cards issued by three-party card schemes, such as Amex, as well as other means of payment, such as non-EUR direct debits, Apple Pay and PayPal – but we’ll continue to monitor the implementation of the surcharge ban (and PSD2) across Europe.

title: Untitled
text: Some aspects of the PSD2 surcharge ban also apply to B2B payments. The surcharge ban applies to EUR payments made by business customers using direct debit or credit transfer (but not payments made using a corporate credit or debit card), where the bank or card issuer of the business customer and payment provider of the merchant (i.e., Stripe) are both located in the EEA.

title: Untitled
text: As with B2C payments, even if the surcharge ban does not apply, PSD2 limits the amount that merchants can surcharge businesses to the cost incurred by the merchant in accepting the particular payment method. If you’re a platform or marketplace, the surcharge ban does not impact the platform or application fee you charge, provided that these fees are not differentiated by payment method.

title: Untitled
text: If you have any questions about your local market or would just like to know more, reach out to Stripe Support .

title: Untitled
text: Keeping your Stripe password secure is essential to protect sensitive financial data and prevent unauthorized access to your funds. A compromised password could result in fraudulent transactions, financial loss, and potential damage to your business's reputation.

title: Untitled
text: If you use the same password on Stripe and a different website, then when that website experiences a data breach, your password might be exposed. An attacker can then try all the credentials exposed in the data breach to gain access to your Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: A password manager generates strong, unique passwords for each website and store them in an encrypted database. When using a password manager, you memorize a single unique master password for the password manager itself, and it can automatically fill in the strong, unique password it generated into every website. Because of this, a password manager makes it faster to log into websites while increasing security.

title: Untitled
text: Password managers can also protect you from phishing attacks. If you have your Stripe password stored in a password manager, but it doesn't offer to automatically fill in the password when you try to sign into Stripe, you should double check that you are on the correct website .

title: Untitled
text: We strongly recommend that you use a password manager and let it generate a secure password for you. However, if you choose to not use a password manager (or if you are looking for ideas for a master password), we recommend that you choose at least four random words from the dictionary and use them as your password.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe updated our Stripe Services Agreement which applies to the use of Stripe services in Canada (on October 30, 2024), and in Australia, the European Economic Area, Gibraltar, Hong Kong, New Zealand, Singapore, Switzerland, the United Kingdom, and the United States (on November 11, 2024) (the “ Relevant Territories ”). As part of this update, we also updated the Stripe Connected Account Agreement (applicable to connected accounts). You can find a summary of the most notable changes, when those changes take effect, and more information below.

title: Untitled
text: The updated terms take effect immediately for new users in the Relevant Territories who sign up on or after the above dates.

title: Untitled
text: For existing Stripe users as of the above dates in the Relevant Territories, the updated terms will take effect on February 1, 2025 (except for Custom or Express connected accounts and other connected accounts without access to a Stripe Dashboard, for whom the updated terms will take effect on March 1, 2025 ).

title: Untitled
text: If you do not agree to the updated terms, you will need to stop using Stripe services and close your Stripe account before these terms become effective. If you have a Stripe Dashboard, you can close your account by following these instructions . If your Stripe account is integrated with a Stripe Connect Platform and you don’t have a Stripe Dashboard, you must contact your Stripe Connect Platform to close your account. Your use of the Stripe services after the applicable effective date will be subject to the updated terms.

title: Untitled
text: You don’t need to take any action to accept the new terms. Connect Platform users with Custom or Express connected accounts and other connected accounts without access to a Stripe Dashboard should follow the guidance below to notify their connected accounts.

title: Untitled
text: You are responsible for notifying your Custom and Express connected accounts and your other connected accounts without access to a Stripe Dashboard of the updated terms by December 31, 2024 . We suggest you use your usual method of updating your connected accounts about important changes (for example, by email). We recommend you send those connected accounts in the Relevant Territories a notice that includes the following information:

title: Untitled
text: Stripe is updating its legal terms. You can read the Connected Account Agreement (incorporating the Stripe Services Agreement) here . The updates to the terms will take effect on March 1, 2025. No action is needed from you, but by continuing to use Stripe’s services on or after that date, you are agreeing to these updated terms.

title: Untitled
text: If you use Connect but have no Custom or Express connected accounts or other connected accounts without access to a Stripe Dashboard, we’ve handled the communication for you by letting affected connected accounts know about the changes.

title: Untitled
text: The updated terms do not apply to your use of Stripe (and your existing terms with Stripe remain applicable), but you are responsible for notifying your connected accounts in the Relevant Territories of the updated terms as mentioned above.

title: Untitled
text: When we update our legal terms, we’re required to send a legal notice to all affected Stripe users — even if you have unsubscribed from our marketing messages. As a Stripe user, you can’t unsubscribe from legal notices.

title: Untitled
text: You can find our updated terms which are labeled with their most recent update date at stripe.com/legal . If you have agreed to other terms with Stripe for the use of Stripe services that take precedence over these online terms, those other terms are unaffected by this change.

title: Gender and Nationality
text: Stripe regularly reviews and updates its verification requirements to stay current with financial regulations and ensure businesses that use Stripe are compliant. For Indian businesses accepting card payments or making transfers, we’re updating how we collect, validate, and verify business information. As a result, you may need to provide updated information. Our goal is to help ensure safe and uninterrupted access to the payments ecosystem for you.

title: Gender and Nationality
text: ﻿﻿ Log in to your Dashboard to see the actions you need to take, and review the resources below to learn more about the type of information you may need to provide. The specific information you need to provide may vary depending on your business type.

title: Gender and Nationality
text: To comply with regulations, we need to collect both the registered address and the trading address for your company. You can enter your pincode, and we'll automatically populate some of the fields for you to make the process easier.

title: Gender and Nationality
text: We will be verifying your PAN for Aadhaar seeding. According to Section 139 AA of the Income Tax Act 1961, everyone who has been assigned a Permanent Account Number (PAN) and is eligible to obtain an Aadhaar number must link their PAN to Aadhaar. If the PAN is not linked to Aadhaar, it will become "inoperative."

title: Gender and Nationality
text: Please ensure that the name and date of birth are updated and match the details you have provided to us .

title: Gender and Nationality
text: Stripe requires all merchants who sell or promote products or services online to provide the URL of their business website, social media profile or mobile application when completing account activation. Going forward, if you are an online business, we will be verifying the following URLs

We will verify that your IEC is active and matches your business name and structure. This is required to comply with updated requirements for accepting international payments.

title: Gender and Nationality

The beneficial owner can be of either Indian or non-Indian nationality. For Indian nationals, their identity will be verified using their PAN. Non-Indian nationals may provide a copy of their passport for verification.

title: Gender and Nationality

title: Gender and Nationality

title: Gender and Nationality
text: We will be verifying your PAN for Aadhaar seeding. According to Section 139 AA of the Income Tax Act 1961, everyone who has been assigned a Permanent Account Number (PAN) and is eligible to obtain an Aadhaar number must link their PAN to Aadhaar. If the PAN is not linked to Aadhaar, it will become "inoperative."

title: Gender and Nationality
text: Please ensure that the name and date of birth are updated and match the details you have provided to us .

title: Gender and Nationality

Typically, you have 14 days from the due date to provide updated information before payouts are paused, and 28 days from the due date before payments are paused

title: Gender and Nationality
text: If you're unable to provide the required information, please contact Stripe Support and we'll work with you to come up with an alternative solution.

title: Gender and Nationality
text: On your Stripe Dashboard: If there are outstanding verification requirements for your account, you will see a red banner at the top of your Dashboard. You can click "Review details" on the banner to see what is needed to verify your account.

title: Gender and Nationality
text: In some cases, if your documents are not accepted for verification, Stripe will send you a feedback email explaining why the document isn't acceptable and what issues were found.

title: Gender and Nationality
text: In some cases, we may ask for additional documents to verify your business. To ensure a smooth and efficient document verification process, please consider these guidelines to prevent any delays or complications:

title: Gender and Nationality
text: Stripe stores verification data securely using access controls and security standards that are at least as stringent as those for handling our own payment compliance and KYC data. We use TLS encrypted connections for data transfer and AES-256 encryption for data at rest. For more information, see: How are you keeping my verification data safe?

title: Untitled
text: We’re actively expanding subscription-based plans to more regions. If your region is supported, you’ll see the option to sign up.

title: Untitled
text: All of our subscription plans require a one-year commitment. Your annual contract begins at 00:00 UTC on the day after you sign up, and runs for one year. Once enrolled, you’re responsible for subscription fees and any applicable additional fees incurred for the full term—even if you schedule a cancellation before your contract ends.

title: Untitled
text: Subscription plans automatically renew for another one-year term unless you schedule a cancellation before the renewal date. To prevent automatic renewal, make sure to cancel your subscription in advance of your renewal date.

title: Untitled
text: Once your current contract period ends, your account will automatically transition to a pay-as-you-go plan and you'll no longer be able to access any unused entitlements or features that are only available through a subscription.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe subscription plans require an annual commitment. When you subscribe, you agree to pay for the full annual term, including any incurred additional fees. Payments are non-refundable, and we don’t offer prorated refunds if you cancel before the end of your term.

title: Untitled
text: All of our subscriptions require an annual commitment. A subscription fee covers product usage up to the entitlement limit for your selected plan during your current term. Some entitlements may incur additional regional fees, such as some tax registrations and tax filings. If usage exceeds your entitlement, overage fees will apply. To learn more about these fees, see Stripe Pricing .

title: Untitled
text: A product usage entitlement is the amount of usage included in your subscription plan. This is the limit you selected when signing up, and it determines how much of the product you can use before incurring overages. Some entitlements may incur additional fees, such as some tax registrations and tax filings. You can see your entitlements and track your usage via the Stripe Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: Overage fees are additional fees incurred when product usage entitlement is exceeded. These fees only apply to usage beyond your selected product entitlement and are billed at the end of your billing period monthly. For Stripe Tax subscriptions, any additional fees will appear as overages.

title: Untitled
text: All Stripe subscriptions require a one-year commitment and begin at 00:00 UTC on the day after you sign up. You're charged your recurring subscription fee at the start of your contract and then at the beginning of each subsequent billing period. Additional fees, including overage fees, are charged separately at the end of the billing period in which they're incurred.

title: Untitled
text: In this example, the usage entitlement is 100,000 USD per month. These are charged at the end of the billing period in which they occur.

title: Untitled
text: Your subscription fee is deducted from your Stripe account balance. Standard terms and conditions for payments made via your Stripe account balance apply.

title: Untitled
text: All of our subscription plans require an annual commitment. Your annual contract starts at 00:00 UTC on the day after you sign up, and ends one year later. After you sign up for a subscription, you’re responsible for paying for the entire year, even if you schedule a cancellation during your current term.

title: Untitled
text: Yes, all of our subscription plans automatically renew on the anniversary date for an additional one-year term. If you don’t want to automatically renew, you need to schedule a cancellation of your subscription before the auto-renew date, as set forth in our Subscription Cancellation Policy .

title: Untitled
text: If you scheduled a subscription cancellation by mistake, you can undo it at any time before the contract renewal date:

title: Untitled
text: The plan will be effective at the start of your next billing period. For example, if you’re charged on the 15th of every month, and you upgrade your plan on October 20, the new upgraded price and usage entitlement is applied effective November 15.

title: Untitled
text: You can’t downgrade your plan below your initial subscription plan during the contract period. For example, if you sign up for the plan with 250,000 USD in Billing volume, you can upgrade to the 500,000 USD Billing volume tier, but can’t downgrade to the 100,000 USD Billing volume tier during the contract period. You can schedule a downgrade to the 100,000 USD tier to go into effect for the next annual contract period.

title: Untitled
text: When you upgrade, your existing plan is canceled and a new subscription with an annual commitment begins. The new plan takes effect at the start of your next billing period and any remaining entitlements from your previous subscription will no longer be available after this date.

title: Untitled
text: If you have an annual Stripe Tax plan at 430 USD per month that started on September 15, 2024 at 00:00 UTC, and you choose to upgrade to a 1,000 USD per month plan on October 31 2024:

title: Untitled

title: Untitled
text: We don’t offer prorated refunds on pre-paid subscriptions. All Stripe subscription plans require an annual commitment. You're responsible for the full subscription fee, including applicable overage fees for the entire term. title: Untitled
text: Taxes are estimated at checkout based on current tax rates. These rates may change, and some jurisdictions may require self-assessment for tax reporting.

title: Untitled
text: Custom pricing is available for companies with large payments volume, high-value transactions, or unique business models. Contact sales to learn more.

title: Untitled
text: Taxually is a Stripe partner that handles tax filing and certain tax registration submissions for various jurisdictions. When you purchase a Stripe Tax subscription, you gain access to registration and filing services with Taxually aligned with your plan’s entitlements. You’ll need to set up an account with Taxually and accept their terms in order to use their services. Stripe will process any applicable fees based on your Stripe Tax subscription plan.

A business makes 1,000 Calculation API calls and doesn’t make any Transaction API calls during the month. The business is charged as API calls are made. Since no Transaction API calls were made, no rebate is applicable. In total, the business is billed for $50 that month.

A business makes 1,000 Calculation API calls and 1,000 Transaction API calls during the month. The business is charged as API calls are made. At the end of the month, the business is rebated for the 1,000 Calculation API calls because up to 10 Calculation API calls are included for every 1 Transactional API call. The business is billed only for 1,000 Transaction API calls and charged $500.
This is an unlikely scenario but may occur if a website has a very low conversion rate or if the Calculations API is implemented in a way that it is called more than needed.

A business makes 1,000 Calculation API calls and 80 Transaction API calls during the month. The business is charged as API calls are made. The business qualifies for a rebate of 10 Calculation API calls per Transaction API call. At the end of the month, the business is rebated for 800 Calculation API calls. The business is then charged for 200 Calculation API calls and 80 Transaction API calls.

title: Users who viewed this Card also viewed:
text: A manually entered card payment is a transaction in which a customer’s card details have been typed into and processed on the Stripe Dashboard or with Stripe Terminal MOTO. This includes the following:

title: Users who viewed this Card also viewed:
text: Transaction fees on cards entered manually in the Stripe Dashboard or with Terminal MOTO are 3.4% + 0.30 USD for businesses on standard pricing based in the US and 3.4% + 0.30 CAD for businesses based in Canada compared to 2.9% + 0.30 USD and 2.9% + 0.30 CAD, respectively, for standard card payments.

title: Users who viewed this Card also viewed:
text: The higher fees reflect the cost of higher fraud rates associated with collecting customer card details by phone or other unencrypted sources. Directly typing in sensitive customer data bypasses much of the security that’s built into Stripe’s online payments. As a result, we see higher fraud rates on manually entered payments, leading to higher costs for Stripe.

title: Users who viewed this Card also viewed:
text: Below are alternatives to consider for more secure and easy-to-use payment options that allow your customer to directly enter their card information:

title: Users who viewed this Card also viewed:
text: In the context of Strong Customer Authentication (SCA) and Japan’s 3DS mandate , card details collected over the phone or by mail do not require authentication. Payments made by manually entering card details are automatically marked as MOTO by Stripe.

title: Users who viewed this Card also viewed:
text: When card information is manually entered into the Dashboard or Terminal MOTO, we can’t verify that it’s being kept secure outside of Stripe. You’re then responsible for ensuring the protection of card data in accordance with PCI compliance requirements. Refer to the PCI DSS compliance guide to better understand PCI requirements.

title: Users who viewed this Card also viewed:
text: If you need to process phone and mail payments via the Dashboard, API, or Stripe Terminal, contact us to enable this feature on your Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe may require users to upload a photo of a government-issued photo ID and a selfie for identity verification to the Dashboard . The photos must be clear and well-lit without any obstructions. Use a mobile device's camera for better quality.

title: Untitled
text: In some cases, Stripe will require you to upload an image of your photo ID and selfie to confirm your identity. You'll need to take a photo of an accepted form of ID, such as a driver's license or passport. Sometimes we’ll also need to capture an image of your face in addition. Due to the highly sensitive nature of your verification documents, Stripe can only accept documents which are uploaded through the Dashboard. Do not send documents by email.

title: Untitled
text: If you don’t receive a text message, you can use a QR code instead to access the link. In the Dashboard there is an option to display a QR code on the screen. Then use your phone’s camera (if QR code detection is supported) or other barcode scanning app to scan the code and access the link.

title: Untitled
text: Check that you’ve given Stripe permission to access your webcam—if you block permissions to your camera, refer to Chrome, Safari, or Edge documentation on allowing access to use your webcam.

title: Untitled
text: If you don't have a webcam, in the Dashboard there is an option to switch to another device. You'll be prompted to enter your mobile phone number and Stripe will send a link to your phone to start the process.

title: Untitled
text: Below are sample answers to common questions that your connected accounts may have about why Stripe or your platform is requesting sensitive personally identifiable information (PII).

title: Untitled
text: Payments regulations aim to create a safer, more secure financial ecosystem by helping prevent crimes like money laundering, fraud, and tax evasion. Stripe, our payment processor, has certain “ Know Your Customer ” (KYC) obligations that require us to collect, verify, and maintain identity information about our users, and for any individuals who ultimately own, control, or direct them. These requirements are frequently updated by Stripe, financial service regulators, card networks, and other financial institutions.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe uses PII to fulfill these KYC obligations. We take your privacy and the security of your data very seriously. Stripe’s security tools and best practices ensure that your sensitive information is safely stored and encrypted . Learn more about the safeguards in place to protect your information: Stripe Privacy Center .

title: Untitled
text: KYC requirements are frequently updated by Stripe, financial service regulators, card networks, and other financial institutions. If, at any time, we are unable to confirm that your business meets these checks or requirements, we may ask you to send us more information or fix the problem. Depending on the severity of the issue, your account may not be able to to payout funds, receive transfers, or accept payments until the issue is resolved. We’ll let you know if that’s the case.

title: Untitled
text: To comply with federal regulations, Stripe must collect and verify KYC information about users who accept payments in the US.

title: Untitled
text: For these checks, Stripe needs to collect specific details to confirm your identity. When a user first onboards with Stripe, Stripe attempts to verify you using the minimum requested information: your legal name, date of birth, and the last 4 digits of your Social Security Number (SSN). If we’re unable to verify your SSN using the last 4 digits, we’ll need to collect all 9 digits.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe collects the full 9-digit SSN for users who accept payments in the US when the total lifetime payments volume reaches $500K. If the full ID number fails verification, you'll need to upload an ID document .

title: Untitled
text: This is in accordance with regulatory obligations that apply to the financial institutions through which Stripe processes payments. These regulations require financial institutions to collect identification numbers directly from their customers and the beneficial owners of their customers. For US-based individuals, the identification number must be an SSN or ITIN.

title: Untitled
text: If you don't provide the updated information, or if Stripe cannot successfully verify your information, then you might not be able to receive payouts and accept payments until the information is provided and verified.

title: Stripereporting
text: Use prebuilt reports to understand basic activity on your account such as payments, payouts, fees, and balance changes. View the reports in the Stripe Dashboard , or download a CSV to complete accounting tasks. Learn more about Stripe’s reporting features .

title: Stripereporting
text: Stripe’s financial reports help you understand and reconcile the activity in your account. You can view summary reports in the Dashboard or download itemized transaction data as a CSV file.

title: Stripereporting
text: Multiple export formats Use Revenue Recognition to download reports in CSV, PDF, or Excel formats for easy analysis and sharing.

title: Additional Information
text: The default time zone in your Stripe account is based on the location in which your Stripe account was registered. For example, if your account was set up with a San Francisco-based business address, your dashboard will reflect times according Pacific Time.

title: Additional Information
text: If you are creating a new Stripe account while logged into an existing account, the new account will inherit the time zone of the existing account.

title: Untitled
text: There are three types of data migrations we can assist you with. Each type involves the secure movement of customer records and their associated payment types:

title: Untitled
text: The Stripe migration team can only import or export customer details if accompanied by the payment details. For importing or exporting customer data that does not include payment details, the Customers API can be used. You can also export customer data without the payment details on the Dashboard .

title: Untitled
text: Citibank has decided to split their operation in Mexico into two separate banking entities: Banamex (Banco Nacional de Mexico), focusing on enterprise and retail banking, and Banco Citi Mexico, focusing on the institutional segment. Stripe’s bank transfer product is based on a partnership with Banco Citi Mexico. The date of this transition is currently scheduled for December 2nd, 2024 .

title: Untitled
text: Stripe’s bank transfer payment method is built using CLABEs that belong to CitiBanamex. As a result of the aforementioned split, Stripe Mexico will be facing some changes. Specifically, we will need to move our product to use a set of new CLABEs that belong to Banco Citi Mexico.

title: Untitled
text: CLABE is the Clave Bancaria Estandarizada, a unique number to identify account numbers in the Mexican financial system. Every CLABE has 18 digits that follow the same structure, “ AAA BBB CCCCCCCCCCC D ” where:

title: Untitled
text: Over the migration phase, you will notice that the CLABEs Stripe generates for your payments will change over to belong to Banco Citi Mexico. After the separation goes into effect, the Account Numbers (ie CLABEs) used for Stripe’s bank transfers will have a new number reflecting the future bank identifier for Banco Citi Mexico, namely, from beginning with “002” they will now begin with “124”.

title: Untitled
text: However, your overall use of Stripe will not change: the dashboard will remain the same, reporting will stay consistent, your ability to generate bank transfer payment intents will remain uninterrupted, etc.

title: Untitled
text: Stripe will substitute CLABEs for your existing & active customer base on the backend. Specifically, we will remove the “old” CLABE and add a “new” one. So, starting on the migration date, any payment intent (e.g. Invoice) that you generate for your customers will automatically have the new CLABE. Any customer receiving a payment request from you will receive the new CLABE in the payment page.

title: Untitled
text: We know that some customers save CLABEs to their bank portals, especially recurring users. For this reason, we suggest that you highlight the change to your customers and ask them to update your CLABE in their own banking portals for any payment sent from December 2nd, 2024 onwards.

title: Untitled
text: If one of your customers mistakenly sends money to an “old” CLABE, the funds will be immediately returned to them, showing in their bank statement and banking app/ website. On your side, you will see the transaction status as “Incomplete” on your Dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: If this should happen, you will need to remind your user to update the “new” CLABE and send the payment again.

title: Untitled
text: We are working closely with Citibank to have an orderly transition with as much lead time as possible. We are in the loop on the details of the migration and are working to make this migration easier for all our users.

title: Untitled
text: As our joint planning progresses, we will look for ways to make your migration process as seamless and transparent as possible.

title: Untitled
text: The current date for the switch-over is December 2nd, 2024 . Our joint work with Citi is ongoing and we continue detailing the specifics of this process.

title: Untitled
text: You can expect to hear from us in the coming weeks as we continue to share more information and increase the frequency of communications as we approach the cutover date.

title: Untitled
text: This form streamlines the account verification process and provides our team with all the relevant details we will need for the migration.

title: Untitled
text: After submitting the form, you will receive a confirmation that the form was received. We will then follow up by email within the next three business days to answer any questions you may have, and to provide you with the next steps for your migration.

title: Untitled
text: If you want to migrate customer card information from a different payment provider to Stripe, contact Stripe support and we will walk you through transferring your sensitive customer information in a secure, PCI-compliant way.

title: Additional Information
text: If you want to migrate your card data from Stripe to another service, we can help ensure that the migration is done securely and in compliance with PCI regulations .

title: Additional Information
text: For PCI-regulated data, such as full credit card numbers, contact us with the name of the processor you are transferring your data to and we will get a secure transfer started.

title: Additional Information
text: For non-PCI-regulated data, such as payment history or subscriptions, this can be exported using the Stripe API or through your Dashboard . You can access that information for as long as your Stripe account is open.

title: Untitled
text: Our copy process will fire webhook events such as customer.created and customer.updated in the destination account, if those are set up in the destination account.

text: We're rolling out the updated requirements for your Custom connected accounts in groups to minimize the disruption to your and your users' businesses. The groupings are based on multiple factors including the number of accounts in each group, the payment volume of accounts, and the types of outstanding requirements.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: Connected accounts that have smaller payment volume are in earlier groups, and we tried to avoid a large percentage of total active accounts (made payouts or accepted payments in the last 180 days) having the same due date.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: Accounts that already meet the updated requirements will also appear in earlier groups. When the updated requirements take effect for these accounts, they will not need to take any further action.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: All connected accounts with the same due date are grouped together and will have the same timeline for pausing payouts and payments if requirements are not met.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: From the Accounts to review page, hover over a single account in the list and select View actions required . This takes you to the connected account's details page to see their individual requirements and due dates.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: If the account has any outstanding existing requirements, they will also appear in the Actions required section and may have earlier due dates. These existing requirements will have an issue status of Currently due or a more specific status.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: If the requirements are still outstanding when they take effect, they will move within the Accounts API from future_requirements to requirements . The status will still be Restricted soon in the Dashboard.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: The date listed in the Dashboard under Due Date is 14 days after the requirements take effect. On the due date, the API will transition from requirements.currently_due to requirements.past_due . The Dashboard status will be Restricted . Payouts are paused at this time.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: Another 14 days later, the API will show requirements.past_due and the Dashboard status will be Restricted and payments will be paused as well.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: Easily see whether payouts and payments are enabled or disabled for any account at the top of the account’s details page next to the colored account status badge.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: You can see the due dates for your accounts on the Accounts to Review page. The due dates reflect their assigned groups. All connected accounts with the same due date are in the same group and will have the same payout pause and payment pause dates.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: On the due date the account will no longer be able to receive payouts. If there are still outstanding requirements 14 days later, they will no longer be able to accept payments.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: As we have been helping platforms, connected accounts, and direct Stripe customers update their verification information, we have strived to minimize disruption to your and your users’ businesses. We started with a clear single deadline to enable platforms to plan and start remediating users.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: As this new policy comes into effect, we are spreading out the due dates to ensure that you have adequate time to work with your customers who require the most support.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: Unfortunately, we are not able to accommodate requests to change due dates for accounts. We have grouped accounts into phases to minimize business disruption by considering your total number of active accounts, their payment volume, and specific requirements.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: Accounts with existing requirements that are currently due will not have a due date listed. These accounts need to provide missing information as a normal course of business and may have their payouts or payments paused sooner than the timelines described above.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: These requirements may be due for a given connected account on a future date after a certain payment volume threshold has been crossed. Once this threshold is reached, the account will become Restricted soon . You and the connected account will have 14 days to provide the updated information before payouts or payments are paused. You can also help your accounts provide the required information at any time in order to get ahead of future restrictions.

title: See when payouts or payments may be paused for your accounts in the API and Dashboard
text: Updated requirements for other types of connected accounts are being enforced on a separate schedule. Due dates for other types of connected accounts reflect the date when their payouts will be paused. Stripe is directly reaching out to these users when the updated requirements become active. These users are able to remediate via their Stripe dashboard, Express dashboard, or embedded components.

title: Untitled
text: If you have Custom connected accounts operating in any of these countries, you may need to update your onboarding flow for the updated requirements. See the table below for more information about the earliest deadlines in each country.

title: Untitled
text: Starting mid-August, see the status of affected connected accounts in the Dashboard Accounts to Review page. To filter by country click More filters > Verification requirement and then check the box(es) for the countries you want to see. See the Custom accounts deadlines FAQ for more details

title: Untitled
text: The dates mentioned above are the earliest possible due dates, and enforcement of individual accounts may vary. These deadlines are subject to change. We’ll notify you of any changes.

title: Untitled
text: When we notify you about updated requirements for a particular country, you’ll see an overview of the actions needed and their associated deadlines on your Stripe Dashboard. Follow documentation on handling verification updates to ensure your accounts are compliant.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: Verification requirements are changing for Canada-based Custom connected accounts accepting card_payments or with transfer capabilities enabled. These requirements must be met so the accounts can continue to accept card payments and receive payouts.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: New Custom connected accounts created on or after November 6, 2024: Must meet the updated requirements during onboarding. Otherwise, they won’t be able to accept payments.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: Existing Custom connected accounts : If your connected accounts have not provided the required information by January 29, 2025 they will not be able to receive payouts. Their payments may be Feb 19, 2025 , if they still have outstanding requirements. paused starting on

title: What are the deadlines?
text: Collect updated information from accounts by January 29, 2025 , so these accounts can continue to receive payouts and to accept payments.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: Send users to your Stripe-hosted onboarding flow or the embedded onboarding component to collect the necessary information. Both update automatically with changing requirements.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: Modify your onboarding flow by November 6, 2024 so that new Custom connected accounts meet the updated requirements. And ensure that you’ve collected information from existing accounts by January 29, 2025 , so that these accounts can continue to receive payouts and to accept payments.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: Modify your onboarding flow : There are a few ways to modify your onboarding flow to satisfy the updated requirements:

title: What are the deadlines?
text: Collect updated information: Your Dashboard and the Accounts API both show which of your accounts need to provide updated information. You can use our new embedded components or Stripe-hosted onboarding flows to collect updated information from these accounts, or submit it via the API.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: See the status of affected connected accounts in the Dashboard's Accounts to review page. To filter by country click, More filters > Verification requirement and then check the box(es) for the countries you want to see.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: There are several features available in your Stripe Dashboard and in the Accounts API that will help you meet the updated requirements.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: The Accounts API now includes future_requirements , indicating requirements that will come into effect at a future date. New verification errors are accessible via requirements.errors and future_requirements.errors .

title: What are the deadlines?
text: Additionally, verification responses specify which information is needed for each account. These will be available via the API automatically for all platforms starting on October 29, 2024 . Review the guide to these API changes and opt in early .

title: What are the deadlines?
text: future_requirements is an API field on the account , person , and capabilities objects to ease the process of adapting to evolving compliance requirements. It provides a preview of upcoming requirement changes for your connected accounts well before the requirement(s) goes into effect, making it easier to see what user onboarding changes to make for new users signing up on your platform, and any additional information existing users need to provide.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: There's no action for you to take for your other types of connected accounts. Your Stripe onboarding flow has automatically updated to handle changing requirements. We'll reach out to any connected accounts that need to provide updated business information.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: If an account doesn't provide the required information by the listed due date, their ability to accept payments and receive payouts will be paused. Typically, the timeframe to provide updated information is within 14 days of the due date to continue receiving payouts, and within 28 days to continue accepting payments. However, that timeframe might vary for certain types of issues.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: The Financial Transactions and Reports Analysis Centre of Canada (FINTRAC) released a new set of regulations in April, 2022 that requires Stripe to register as a money services business in Canada. This introduces additional Know Your Customer and Know Your Business requirements that impact connected accounts with either the card_payments or transfers capability.

title: What are the deadlines?
text: Yes. As regulatory requirements evolve globally, we expect our onboarding requirements to continue changing as well.  If you use embedded onboarding components or Stripe-hosted onboarding, then Stripe automatically updates your onboarding flow to handle the latest verification requirements. If you use API-based onboarding, you’ll need to manually modify your onboarding flow whenever requirements change.

title: Untitled
text: If the last 4 digits fail to verify at onboarding, Reps will need to provide the full 9 digits at onboarding

title: Untitled
text: A Representative (Rep) is defined as a person with significant responsibility to control, manage, or direct the organization; and is authorized by the organization to agree to Stripe’s terms. For a representative, the full 9 digits are required at $500K only if no Owners are listed on the account.

title: Untitled
text: When we’re unable to verify information provided by your connected accounts, we’ll surface detailed verification responses error codes in the Accounts object .

title: Untitled
text: To align with the IRS reporting thresholds for Forms 1099-K, 1099-NEC, and 1099-MISC, we’re updating the threshold at which we verify the TIN to when your payments volume reaches $600 or within 30 days of first charge, whichever comes first.

title: Untitled
text: For new connected accounts, if a statement descriptor is not provided, it is prefilled using the following supplied fields (in this order): business_profile[name] (“doing business as”), business_profile[url] , the legal entity name (either individual[first_name] + individual[last_name] or company[name] ).

title: Untitled
text: In addition, if the statement descriptor prefix is not provided, it’s prefilled from the first 10 characters of the statement descriptor.

title: Untitled
text: For existing accounts, if a statement descriptor or prefix fails verification, your accounts will be required to update this information. Stripe will not modify these fields using our prefill logic.

title: Google Pay and Apple Pay unavailable for merchants and customers in India on Stripe Checkout and Stripe Elements.
text: For domestic & international payments in India, Stripe supports Visa and Mastercard (including Maestro) as well as American Express (Amex). Do note there are some restrictions applied for processing through AMEX.

title: Google Pay and Apple Pay unavailable for merchants and customers in India on Stripe Checkout and Stripe Elements.

text: We currently do not support Google Pay and Apple Pay on Stripe Checkout and Elements for Stripe accounts and customers in India. See Apple documentation for more information on supported countries.

title: Untitled
text: The RBI has introduced these measures to protect cardholder safety and provide additional security measures for card payments. Learn more here .

title: Untitled
text: An e-mandate is a form of authorization provided by cardholders to issuing banks that grants permission for recurring payments to be collected from the card. Any recurring payment arrangements (e.g. monthly subscriptions to OTT services) need an associated e-mandate to be successful. The e-mandate needs to be registered and then validated through AFA like 3DS. Learn more about e-mandates and other requirements.

title: Untitled
text: Most banks in India have updated their systems to support and manage e-mandates for cards. Major card issuing banks also support non-INR currency mandates on internationally accepted cards issued by them.

title: Untitled
text: We have developed a flexible solution through Stripe Billing to comply with the regulations. Stripe Billing's solutions support our users in registering e-mandates and issuing pre-debit notifications to their customers. We will also trigger dynamic authentication, allowing your customers to complete 3DS only when required (e.g., for transactions above the RBI’s threshold).

title: Untitled
text: If you have recurring transactions from India-issued cards that are failing, please follow our impact assessment guide and update your Stripe Billing integration for the e-mandate changes. Our guide explains how to update your integration to comply with this regulation.

title: Untitled
text: Businesses that have not updated their integrations to support e-mandate changes will likely encounter a disruption to your subscription lifecycle management (e.g., decreased renewal rates) due to the required re-registration of existing subscriptions and additional 3DS requirements. This disruption is industry-wide and not unique to businesses that use Stripe.

title: Untitled
text: Will this affect me if I am a business outside of India taking payments from customers with India issued cards?

title: Untitled
text: Stripe supports non-INR e-mandates only for specific currencies and for international (non-IN) businesses. A small set of issuing banks might still not support e-mandates for a particular currency yet. If an e-mandate cannot be created, you should consider alternatives such as bringing your customers back on-session to complete the payment with 3DS.

title: Untitled
text: The following guide can help you determine if your business is impacted by the RBI directive on the processing of e-mandates for recurring transactions, including subscriptions and bill payments.

title: Untitled
text: Only card issuers and card networks are permitted to store the card data of an India issued card for transactions processed through payment service providers licensed by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). Payment aggregators (such as Stripe) will have to use network tokens for payment processing instead of the actual credit/debit card number.

title: Untitled
text: These regulations mainly affect businesses based in India. Card networks have launched Card on File (CoF) tokenization services to comply with these requirements.

title: Untitled
text: Network tokens are offered by card networks such as Visa and MasterCard, to replace the actual credit/debit card number for online payments. They reduce the risk of sensitive card data being exposed as only the card networks will retain this information.

title: Untitled
text: You’re most likely to be affected if your business is based in India and mainly have customers paying with domestic cards.

title: Untitled
text: Tokenization requirements apply to transactions processed by an India-licensed service provider paid by India-issued cards. If you (or, in the case of platforms that are outside India, your connected accounts) are not registered in India and consequently not supported by Stripe India, tokenization of card information is not required.

title: Untitled
text: For getting consent from your customers, if you don’t want to build your own consent flow, we have launched Stripe Managed Tokenization Consent to automatically collect consent on behalf of your customers. Please see the Guide for Indian government regulations on network tokenization for more details.

title: Untitled
text: Once you’ve made these changes, we’ll be able to tokenize cards on your behalf. We’re currently rolling out our tokenization solution to Stripe users in preview. We will contact you when we’re ready to onboard your Stripe account.

title: Untitled
text: Refunds on India-issued card transactions can only be initiated for a period of 90 days following the transaction. After this window, the payment will no longer be eligible for a refund.

title: Untitled
text: This will depend on the configurations specified by the card networks, which are still being discussed. Please continue to follow these FAQs for the latest guidance.

title: Untitled
text: You can save card details to set up future payments through Stripe Checkout, Setup Intents, Payment Intents and other APIs. These will trigger the cardholder to complete 3DS authentication. Stripe will tokenize the card only when 3DS authorization is successful.

title: Untitled
text: Sole proprietorships, LLPs, and companies participating in the India preview can export up to a maximum of 30,000 USD per transaction.

title: Untitled
text: We generally do not support transfer of money from non-India platforms to India Stripe accounts (for example, Deliveroo does not work with Stripe India, as this involves transfer of money from a non-India, non-US platform to an Indian account). We do support this functionality for US platforms (that is, US platforms can pay out to connected accounts in India).

title: Untitled
text: Among others, we currently do not support the exports of gems and jewellery, money transfer business, drop-shipping, and we do not support exporters that ship from warehouses outside of India.

title: Untitled
text: All Indian users processing international transaction will get "payment advice" or "payee advice" emailed directly to their account from Standard Chartered Bank (SCB).

title: Untitled
text: Payment advice is evidence that a business has received export payments that originated outside India. Present the payment advice to your bank to obtain a Foreign Inward Remittance Certificate (FIRC).

title: Untitled
text: A FIRC verifies that an individual or business has brought funds into India that were received as payment in foreign currency from outside India. A FIRC is issued by the authorized Indian bank of the beneficiary and is particularly important for exporters, freelancers, and service providers who receive international payments to comply with export laws, claim potential tax benefits, and qualify for export promotion incentives where available through government schemes.

title: Untitled
text: Payouts are processed automatically on a daily basis. Manual, weekly, and monthly payout schedules aren’t available for accounts in India.

title: Untitled
text: Payouts aren’t posted during the weekend or public holidays. If the expected post date falls on a weekend or holiday, it’s paid out on the following business day.

title: Untitled
text: Daily payout funds paid out to your bank account include payments processed five business days prior for international cards and two business days prior for Indian cards.

title: Untitled
text: There is a seven day waiting period for the first payout. Several factors can extend the waiting period, including operating in a high-risk industry. Stripe processes subsequent payouts daily according to the funds availability timelines listed above.

title: Untitled
text: Funds from domestic and export transactions are paid out separately in INR. If you process both domestic and export payments, you might have two INR payouts on the same day. The balance from export transactions is labelled “International” when you view your payouts in the Stripe dashboard.

title: Untitled
text: To comply with local Know Your Customer (KYC) regulations , Stripe performs automated verifications on the data you provided when creating your Stripe account. For a variety of reasons, the automated verification did not succeed in your case. This could be due to the database downtime, minor mismatches in entity names (e.g. Pvt vs. Private, Ltd. vs. Limited), or other technical issues.

title: Untitled
text: Beyond a certain threshold, this will lead to your payouts being paused until we receive a soft copy of the necessary documents. During this time, be assured that there will be no disruption in your ability to collect payments.

title: Untitled
text: To correct, upload the necessary documentations by clicking on the link provided in the email we have sent you. We accept these documents to validate your information:
